column13: Fix spelling errors detected by lintian
column20:
Debian's lintian tool checks for common mistakes in source and binary packages. One of its checks is to look for common mis-spellings in the binaries.
Based on a patch by Fabian Greffrath against an earlier version of yquake2.

column20:
For deterministic/reproducible builds (where the same source and
toolchain can be verified to produce the same binary, allowing
maliciously substituted binaries to be detected) it is desirable to
take the software's idea of the build date from the build system;
otherwise, the real-time clock at the time of building affects the
result, making it non-reproducible.
SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH is a distribution-neutral specification for how
to do that. It is meant to be set by meta-build systems such as
dpkg or RPM, using a date/time that is already part of the source code,
for example the date of the latest git commit, the date in
the package's debian/changelog, or the date in the RPM spec file.
See https://reproducible-builds.org/specs/source-date-epoch/ for the
specification of SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH, or https://reproducible-builds.org/
for more information on reproducible builds in general.

column21:
I'm curious what benefit you're deriving from having the two build systems. I think in every other project I've seen that has two build systems (whether make + CMake,  Automake + CMake or Automake + nmake) the motivation for the second build system has been to support MSVC on Windows, but yquake2 explicitly doesn't?
If one build system is intended to be strongly supported and the other is a second-class citizen, I'd prefer to use the more strongly supported one (whichever that is) in the Debian packages. I don't personally like CMake, but I already maintain another Debian package that relies on it (OpenJK).

column21: CMake is crap. It may be better then Automake, but that doesn't make it a good build system. The only reason for yq2 having CMake support is that the CMake supporters complained loudly and someone volunteered to do the dirty work... You're right. At this point there's no reason for supporting the SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH  stuff in CMake since most (all?) distributions use the Makefile to build the packages. Even the official Windows binaries are build through the Makefile. If someone really want's to have reproduceable builds with CMake he can provide support for it.

I'm not completely clear on which modules are meant to be allowed to include which headers. This could either be resolved by having savegame.c include common.h, or by having savegame.c repeat the same #ifndef/#define that common.h does. Which would you prefer?

column13: Optionally link libopenal at compile time
column20:
In Linux distributions, having the executable depend on the right
libraries and arrange for them to be installed is straightforward,
and there's a lot of infrastructure for tracking which library
version a particular executable needs, including making sure we have
a version that contains all of the symbols that were used. Loading
libopenal at runtime defeats that infrastructure.
The ability to substitute a different-but-compatible libopenal,
or operate with reduced functionality without libopenal, might
still be desirable for generic/portable binary releases.
The CMake build system already linked the executable to
${OPENAL_LIBRARY} anyway, so it is already a hard dependency in that
build system.

column13: savegame: ensure that BUILD_DATE is defined
column20:
The game code does not include common.h, so it needs to redo this
part for builds without SOURCE_DATE_EPOCH, where BUILD_DATE will
not have been passed in from the outside.
Signed-off-by: Simon McVittie smcv@debian.org

column13: Change openal options in Makefile to fix build failure on Mac OSX 10.…
column20:
…9.5\n\n
Hi. This is my first pull request ever. I'm on Mac OSX 10.9.5.

Building immediately after forking:

Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64:
"_alBuffer3f", referenced from:
      _QAL_Init in qal.o
[and a bunch of similar errors and...]
 ld: symbol(s) not found for architecture x86_64
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make[1]: *** [release/quake2] Error 1
make: *** [client] Error 2


Building after setting DLOPEN_OPENAL = no:

ld: library not found for -lopenal
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make[1]: *** [release/quake2] Error 1
make: *** [client] Error 2



Setting DLOPEN_OPENAL back to yes, and adding Darwin openal to the INCLUDE and LDFLAGS blocks results in the same errors as 1.


Setting DLOPEN_OPENAL = no and leaving the new openal additions builds successfully and appears to have no bugs.


I do not know exactly why this is happening. I am not familiar with makefiles.
Thanks for your work on this project! I was overjoyed to get Quake 2 running on my Mac laptop!

column13: OpenGL3 Renderer, renderers are DLLs again
column20:
A totally awesome OpenGL3 (3.2 core) renderer, that looks mostly like the old one, which is still available, as they're both separate libs.
Also some small fixes to the GL1 renderer.
Note that the loading of the renderer lib and its public interface is pretty similar to the old one we removed when we moved the renderer into the executable, but it's slightly different and incompatible to old ones.
Windows binaries: https://deponie.yamagi.org/quake2/misc/quake2-gl3-test1.zip
Source Code archive to build yourself (esp. relevant on non-Windows platforms like Linux and OSX): https://github.com/DanielGibson/yquake2/archive/render_dll.zip
In the Video menu select the OpenGL 3.2 renderer by pressing your left/right arrow keys, afterwards apply (select apply with down-arrow, then press your Enter key).
The window title will tell you which renderer is currently used.
Ok, so some notes about what this can do:

Gamma (vid_gamma cvar), intensity (gl3_intensity cvar, makes textures look more intense and brighter) and overbrightbits (gl3_overbrightbits cvar, lets you adjust darkness of shadows) are applied in the shader and can be changed in realtime (without vid_restart or anything, just change the cvars). Intensity and overbrightbits used to be limited to integral values or even just 1,2,4; now these can be any decimal value, like 1.5
Dynamic lights are also applied via shader and thus are not limited to the lightmap resolution and look smoother
Dynamic lights now should work on all brush based entities. In the old renderer they only worked on some doors (and normal walls), but not on rotating things.
Particles look a bit softer, as they fade out towards their edges
Lightmaps look the same, but they are blended in the shader (both onto the base surface texture and with each other in case of dynamic lightmaps, like flickering lights, switchable lights etc)
Screenshots can now be taken in JPG, PNG, BMP (and of course still TGA) format, with both the new and the old renderer. See 9462063 for some details
I tried to keep the code compatible to OpenGL ES3 - but I didn't try that yet. Unfortunately, OpenGL ES2 support (for RPi etc) would be harder, because it lacks UBOs (Uniform Buffer Objects) that I use. Anyway, if anyone wants to port this to mobile platforms or whatever might be using OpenGL ES3, it should be easy.
The code should be mostly cleaner and more straightforward than the old renderer, because it doesn't have special cases depending on what the hardware supports, it only uses things available on all hardware that supports OpenGL3.2. (To be fair, the worst thing in the GL1 code probably was multitexturing which has already been removed)

Intensity and overbrightbits used to be limited to integral values or even just 1,2,4; now these can be any decimal value, like 1.5

Dynamic lights now should work on all brush based entities. In the old renderer they only worked on some doors (and normal walls), but not on rotating things.

(To be fair, the worst thing in the GL1 code probably was multitexturing which has already been removed)

column13: OpenGL3 Renderer, renderers are DLLs again
column20:
A totally awesome OpenGL3 (3.2 core) renderer, that looks mostly like the old one, which is still available, as they're both separate libs.
Also some small fixes to the GL1 renderer.
Note that the loading of the renderer lib and its public interface is pretty similar to the old one we removed when we moved the renderer into the executable, but it's slightly different and incompatible to old ones.
Windows binaries: https://deponie.yamagi.org/quake2/misc/quake2-gl3-test1.zip
Source Code archive to build yourself (esp. relevant on non-Windows platforms like Linux and OSX): https://github.com/DanielGibson/yquake2/archive/render_dll.zip
In the Video menu select the OpenGL 3.2 renderer by pressing your left/right arrow keys, afterwards apply (select apply with down-arrow, then press your Enter key).
The window title will tell you which renderer is currently used.
Ok, so some notes about what this can do:

Gamma (vid_gamma cvar), intensity (gl3_intensity cvar, makes textures look more intense and brighter) and overbrightbits (gl3_overbrightbits cvar, lets you adjust darkness of shadows) are applied in the shader and can be changed in realtime (without vid_restart or anything, just change the cvars). Intensity and overbrightbits used to be limited to integral values or even just 1,2,4; now these can be any decimal value, like 1.5
Dynamic lights are also applied via shader and thus are not limited to the lightmap resolution and look smoother
Dynamic lights now should work on all brush based entities. In the old renderer they only worked on some doors (and normal walls), but not on rotating things.
Particles look a bit softer, as they fade out towards their edges
Lightmaps look the same, but they are blended in the shader (both onto the base surface texture and with each other in case of dynamic lightmaps, like flickering lights, switchable lights etc)
Screenshots can now be taken in JPG, PNG, BMP (and of course still TGA) format, with both the new and the old renderer. See 9462063 for some details
I tried to keep the code compatible to OpenGL ES3 - but I didn't try that yet. Unfortunately, OpenGL ES2 support (for RPi etc) would be harder, because it lacks UBOs (Uniform Buffer Objects) that I use. Anyway, if anyone wants to port this to mobile platforms or whatever might be using OpenGL ES3, it should be easy.
The code should be mostly cleaner and more straightforward than the old renderer, because it doesn't have special cases depending on what the hardware supports, it only uses things available on all hardware that supports OpenGL3.2. (To be fair, the worst thing in the GL1 code probably was multitexturing which has already been removed)
column21:
Daniel put a lot of work and even more time into this. This new renderer is likely the best "classic look" renderer ever written for Quake II. To use it an OpenGL 3.2 compliant GPU is required. Be aware that some drivers - say 'hello' to the Intel Windows driver - are really crappy and slow. In out tests this new renderer is considerably faster than the old OpenGL 1.4 renderer if a strong GPU and a good driver is used. With slow GPUs and bad drivers it may be slightly slower, but in general stays above ~90 FPS. Anti aliasing is somewhat more as expensive than with OpenGL 1.4, mostly due to the use of fragment shaders.
Before this can be merged more testing is required. I'll play through the game at least once. In the medium term (after the merge) some smaller features are still missing:

vid_ref should be renamed to vid_renderer for compatibility with old config files.
Add the renderer selection back to the video menu.
Document all cvars. That's long overdue.
cmake is currently broken.

And some tasks I've forgotten. ;)

column21:
Windows binaries can be found here: https://deponie.yamagi.org/quake2/misc/quake2-gl3-test1.zip
They're build from this branch plus one missing pull request fixing the item order in the video menu. Since Daniel opened the pull request several bugs were fixed and the look and feel was tweaked to match the removed multitexturing render path of the old OpenGL 1.4 renderer. In fact this new render is much closer to the old renderer with multitexturing than the old renderer with "classic" rendering.
Have fun with testing this. :)

column21:
Cool, glad you like it! Have fun and report any issues :)
BTW, you can fine-tune the visual appearance even further with the gl3_intensity, gl3_overbrightbits and vid_gamma CVars (ok, the last one is old and can even be configured via video menu)
The looks of the particles can be tuned with  gl3_particle_fade_factor (higher value makes them look less soft/fuzzy) and gl3_particle_size

column21:
Hmm it could be that Sys_GetBinaryDir() (see src/backends/generic/misc.c) doesn't work on OpenBSD.
It's supposed to return the directory the quake2 executable is in and is used in VID_LoadRefresh() (src/backends/generic/vid.c) to load the renderers (which are supposed to lie next to the executable)

column21: OTOH, when Sys_GetBinaryDir() fails it should just return an empty string, so VID_LoadRefresh() should basically call (through Sys_LoadLibrary()) dlopen("ref_gl1.so", RTLD_LAZY); which should at least work if $PWD is the directory the quake2 executable and ref_gl1.so are in.

column21:
There is no way to obtain the currently running executable path on OpenBSD. Additionally we install the binary into /usr/local/bin/quake2 and all game data and .so files to /usr/local/share/yquake2/.
This has been working fine so far when compiled using:
MAKE_FLAGS = config WITH_SYSTEMWIDE=yes WITH_SYSTEMDIR=${PREFIX}/share/${N}
systemdir resolves to /usr/local/share/yquake2/
I did try running it by changing the current working directory to /usr/local/share/yquake2/ but face the same error.
I will add a gist here in a second with full output from a test run.
The gist: https://gist.github.com/mulander/b6ada12f9bbb31fba69761bc5a47b6b7

column21:
can you try running the game without installing it?
from the release/ directory where the binaries are located after compiling
you can set the directory the data is in with ./quake2 +set basedir /path/to/quake2/
for Linux we suggest to keep all binaries in the same directory (game.so in the baseq2/ subdirectory next to the executable of course) and then symlinking the executable to /usr/bin/ or whatever is on your $PATH.
For OpenBSD it won't work if it's not possible to get the executable path, so you may need a shellscript in /usr/bin/ that switches to the directory the binaries are in first.

column21:
Sys_LoadLibrary <ref_gl1.so> failed: File not found
is returned from:
 11 void *                                                                                                                                                                                                                        
 10 Sys_LoadLibrary(const char *path, const char *sym, void **handle)                                                                                                                                                             
  9 {                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
  8         void *module, *entry;                                                                                                                                                                                                 
  7                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
  6         *handle = NULL;                                                                                                                                                                                                       
  5                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
  4         module = dlopen(path, RTLD_LAZY);                                                                                                                                                                                     
  3                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
  2         if (!module)                                                                                                                                                                                                          
  1         {                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
517                 Com_Printf("%s <%s> failed: %s\n", __func__, path, dlerror());                                                                                                                                                
  1                 return NULL;                                                                                                                                                                                                  
  2         } 
note I changed the output to make sure what's used as the path.
Regarding dlopen on OpenBSD the man page states.

The path parameter can be specified as either an absolute pathname to a shared library or just the name of the shared library itself. When an absolute pathname is specified, only the path provided will be searched for the shared library. When just a shared library is specified, the same paths will be searched that are used for “intrinsic” shared library searches.

the string "ref_gl1.so" is not an absolute path hence it's not searched for in the current directory. I assume it searches /usr/lib, /usr/local/lib and other places where system wide libs are expected.
Just to test this assumption. I copied the ref_gl1.so and ref_gl3.so to /usr/local/lib and have the game running.

great, thanks for testing!
maybe we'll just make Sys_BinaryDir() return "./" then if it can't figure out the actual binary dir?
(why does OpenBSD not have a way to get the binary dir? :-/)

column21: There already is a WITH_SYSTEMDIR which allowed the binaries to be separated from the game folder. Perhaps defaulting to that would be a cleaner solution as it's an absolute path and can be defined externally by package managers? I am also just considering installing the .so files in /usr/local but waiting for feedback on that.

column21:
Well, originally the WITH_SYSTEMDIR was meant for game data..
but it's also used to load the game.so (because for mods it kinda is part of the game data)..
and before we put the renderer back into a lib, quake2 was pretty much self-contained (except for game.so)..
and then we added that rpath hack with SYSTEMDIR/lib so one could more easily use a custom libsdl2 (back when it wasn't readily available in most distros)..
and some packages used the systemdir for both game data and binaries..
It's a bit of a mess and I'm not sure yet how best to resolve it without breaking too much stuff.
One reason we want to have all the binaries (esp. quake2 executable and render libs) in the same path (vs looking for render libs in all the places we look for game data) is to make sure people don't just update one part of their q2 installation and report weird bugs.

column21:
maybe we'll just make Sys_BinaryDir() return "./" then if it can't figure out the actual binary dir?

I'm leaning towards agreeing with this proposal. I can repackage yquake2 to place binaries the way you suggest (all in the same directory with game data and .so files) then providing a shell wrapper that will change the current directory to the same one as the binary. I do need however a way to make sure the game will look for everything in /usr/local/share/yquake2/. This seems covered by WITH_SYSTEMDIR but the Sys_BinaryDir change will still be needed for the game to load the .so from the current working directory.
Let me know what you decide and I will act accordingly on our side.

column21: We now have documentation for package/port maintainers: https://github.com/yquake2/yquake2/blob/master/stuff/packaging.md

Hmm, I think the old joystick code (and thus also this code) is not that useful today, where the most popular joystick-like devices (especially for FPS) are XBox/Playstation-style gamepads ("controllers") with two analog sticks, where one stick is used for forward/backward + strafe left/right, and the other for looking up/down and turning left/right.
A further problem with joystick-like devices is that the axis numbers are not consistent between devices, so hardcoded assumptions about the meaning of axis0 and axis1 (even worse: every further axis) will cause trouble.
So we'd need:

support for at least 6 axes (4 axes for the two analog sticks, and I think that sometimes the controller's DPad is represented as two axes - which axis is which varies per device)
configurable action per axis

forward/backward
strafe left/right
look up/down
turn left/right


maybe make all axis invertible?

Furthermore I'm not sure if lookstrafe and freelook should be taken into account here, or can just be ignored (does anyone want to use them with joysticks/gamepads/...?)

Joysticks support is what I was waiting for a long time! Could you please implement axis support and loading mappings config from gamecontrollerdb.txt (https://github.com/gabomdq/SDL_GameControllerDB)?

SDL2's gamecontroller API allows loading those mappings and then one can either use the controller events or https://wiki.libsdl.org/SDL_GameControllerGetBindForAxis etc to do the logical mapping yourself and continue to use joystick events.
But IMHO that is not overly important (as long as action for axis can be configured), more of a convenience feature.

now this looks a lot better!
however, some things that could be improved:

I think for Quake2 (and FPS games in general), using the  triggers as axes for movement/looking is not that useful - I guess most people will want to use them like normal buttons, probably for shooting
related: On some (many?) controllers (e.g. PS2-like), the triggers are buttons and thus will probably create two events: one SDL_CONTROLLER_AXIS_TRIGGERLEFT (or RIGHT) event and one SDL_JOYBUTTONDOWN event
some kind of calibration or deadzone support (maybe as "deadzone start" and "deadzone end" values?) would be useful probably.. but might need UI (menu) support to be usable, which might be quite painful in Quake2. Maybe people can use their operating system for calibration instead..

I haven't actually tested the code yet, this are just some thoughts after reading the code

I have DualShock like joystic with 4 axis, triggers generated only "button" events. So if player like to map trigger to attack action, by defaults code for now export all buttons without relation to kind of such buttons. Code see all buttons as joystick buttons, so we can use more than ten buttons as we have with gamecontrollers. Also triggers axis is not mapped to move actions by default for now on code. I have added logic for minimal threshold/deadzones for axis.
User can use dpad(hat buttons) for navigation in menu.
Also i have added minimal code for haptic feedback(disabled by default: joy_harpic_level=0), current code can generate only feedback to actions for navigation in menu and click to attack button. For enable set joy_harpic_level=1.

With Xbox360 controllers, the triggers are real axes and only generate axis events, no button events, so with those the fallback to SDL_JOYBUTTONDOWN doesn't work.
I'd suggest adding K_TRIG_LEFT and K_TRIG_RIGHT key definitions.
Then, when handling SDL_CONTROLLER_AXIS_TRIGGERLEFT you check whether joy_axis_triggerleft is either "none" or "", and if it is you create a button down event (Key_Event(K_TRIG_LEFT, down, true);), otherwise you do whatever you're already doing for the axis (same for right trigger of course).
Only problem is that you'll also need to generate a key up event once the trigger is not pressed anymore.

Ok, i will create such code.
Also are you intrested in haptic feedback for gun's and explosions? (I don't have solution for it, but think about it).

Haptic feedback sounds cool! (As long as people can switch it off if they don't like it)
I have no idea how hard it'd be to achieve that, or if it's even possible without changing (=> breaking) the API between game.dll and client or the network protocol (I think  we'd like to avoid both things).
But please try it :)
I'd suggest doing that after the "normal" joystick/controller code is done, in a separate branch - so we could merge this without waiting for haptic feedback to be done (I can imagine it needs quite some testing and maybe discussion on improvements etc).
Do you can check what values generated by trigger axis? I think for now use abs(axis.value) > 16384 (half of full range) as condition.

The trigger axis has value 0 when not pressed and up to 32767 when pressed.
Luckily (no idea if we can rely on this for every platform and device), I even get an event with value 0 when not pressing anymore (=> you could use that case for button up)
I think you could already register the event at <16.000, around 5000 should be enough I think? (Maybe you could just use the configurable threshold for that?)
@DanielGibson @Yamagi Could you please review changes?
I have made #227 - it contains initial code for check haptic feedback, if you like to test - you can try this branch.

Sorry we haven't gotten around to properly review and merge this yet, Yamagi and me are both really busy at the moment.
I hope I'll find some time at the end of next week, but I can't promise it - but this is not forgotten :)

Ok, we tested it a bit, some notes:

please make sure the game still builds with SDL1.2 (even if joystick support doesn't work there)
I had to set joy_sidesensitivity -1 because strafing left and right was wrong on my (xbox360) gamepad - I guess this should fixed in code so it works as expected (move left analog stick to the left -> strafe left) by default
I had to set jaw and pitch sensitivity way down (~0.3) to be able to aim => maybe scale it down a bit by default?
when navigating in the menu there is no way to go back with the controller (like with Esc on a keyboard)
maximum movement speed seems to be walking speed - should be running speed (at least if "always run" is on)
when navigating the menu with the hat the console is spammed with "HAT_* is unbound, hit F4 to set" messages - that's uncool (especially in the menu where the hat is actually used)
when pressing other unbound keys (even in game), like joy8, no such messages are printed (here it might be useful to bind those keys via console)
haptic feedback feels inconsistent - shooting (at enemies) rumbles more than being shot, if a parasite (dog-like thing) attacks you, there is no rumbling at all. running (only possible via keyboard, see above) also causes rumbling, it probably shouldn't

All in all it seems pretty good, thanks a lot so far and sorry for the late reply!
(Yamagi will comment on the code later)

Okay, now my part:

vid.c line 104: We can and and should add more resolutions to Quake II. For example 2560x1440 is missing too. We can merge you code like it is but should add the other missing resultions before the next release. Or you could add them.
input.c line 625: If more than a few lines are taken from ioquake3 we should add their author the license header of that file.
input.c: Like @DanielGibson already said the old SDL 1.2 is broken, several #ifdef are missing. It may be  a good idea to move the haptic stuff to a separate file and #ifdef the whole file out.
Key_GetKey() is now unused and should be removed.
stb_img.h is contributed code. Don't change it even if the compiler warnings are annoying.
menu.c: Using the empty lines for the joystick stuff is rather confusing since the options are scattered around. What about replacing lookspring and lookstrafe with the joystick stuff if it's enabled?
In general axis should be treated as axis and buttons as buttons. Treating axis as buttons makes navigation with them hard to impossible.
And don't register the cvars if the joystick subsystem isn't loaded. That's super confusing and will lead to bug reports. :)

Thank you.
I have fixed/reverted such:

Fix build with SDL 1.2
Move video modes
Oposite direction on joy_sidesensitivity
Add notes about code reuse from ioquake3
Revert changes in stb_img.h

"I had to set jaw and pitch sensitivity way down (~0.3) to be able to aim => maybe scale it down a bit by default?"
maximum movement speed seems to be walking speed - should be running speed (at least if "always run" is on)

It can be related to controller/joystick - i don't have any universal solutions for it. I have same movement speed with my joystick as with buttons (joystick_forwardmove *= cl_forwardspeed->value;), or like it. Try to change sensitivity to bigger value. Authors of original code base proposed to use separate configuration for each joystick.

"haptic feedback feels inconsistent - shooting (at enemies) rumbles more than being shot, if a parasite (dog-like thing) attacks you, there is no rumbling at all. running (only possible via keyboard, see above) also causes rumbling, it probably shouldn't"

Also can be related to joystick - i have some noname joystick - and i am not sure what will be correct feedback. I can set other value to magnitude and time period for some weapons, if you like. Code also generated feedback for step sound - so running also have some feedback.

"when navigating the menu with the hat the console is spammed with "HAT_* is unbound, hit F4 to set" messages - that's uncool (especially in the menu where the hat is actually used)"
"when pressing other unbound keys (even in game), like joy8, no such messages are printed (here it might be useful to bind those keys via console)"

I will try to resolve it in next version.

Maybe add additional line in each menu like "go back" ?

menu.c: Using the empty lines for the joystick stuff is rather confusing since the options are scattered around. What about replacing lookspring and lookstrafe with the joystick stuff if it's enabled?

Hey, that looks good. I just had a look and found only two small problems:

In input.c line 1193 Com_Printf("------------------------------------\n\n"); should be moved to the bottom of that function. Otherwise some output is not in the "input block".
In the options menu the internal order of the elements doesn't match the visible order. That can be seen when scrolling the menu from top to bottom. That's likely caused by adding the menu elements in a wrong order. I would suggest to remove the blank line under "invert mouse" and move everything below it one line up. And yes, the menu system is crap. ;)

Otherwise I'm happy. Just one questions: Is there a way to bind axis through the menu? I'm not even sure that the bind system is able to do such thing but it would be nice.
And the 'lookspring' cvar is indeed unused. Go ahead and remove it.

@Yamagi thank you, fixed.

Just one questions: Is there a way to bind axis through the menu?

Off the top of my head - we can do it in such way:

create separate menu where we will set some flag "bind axis" before enter and unset after exit of such menu (It will fully hide any additional fake events ralated to axis movement).
inside of such menu we will have rows with "direction options" like:

sidemove <leftx>
updown <righty>
......


in inputs.c  if "bindaxis" is true - move for axis will produce key_event.

So it will be good candidate for improvements in next PR :-)
Yes, let's make a separate PR for that or even leave it as it is. I think we can merge this now if @DanielGibson is okay with it.
Merged. Thank you! :)

It is expected behavior for now, code use initial joystick button events and controller axis events. SDL hide button events for triggers, so when user clicks trigger button - code will receive only trigger axis event. So joysticks(not controllers) without trigger axis will never receive any events(trigger button).
So use joystick events will be more flexible because it provide up to 32 buttons and never hide events. Controller can have up to 14 buttons. Also controller can have only 6 axis but if user has joystick with bigger amount of axis user can remap it by SDL_GAMECONTROLLERCONFIG.
As temporary solution set 'joy_axis_trigger{left,right}' to 'none' and bind 'joy#' to actions for triggers.

column13: Fix opengl linking for the renderers.
column20:
The variable yquake2RendererLinkerFlags is used to store the linker flags for opengl but the empty variable yquake2OpenGLLinkerFlags is used when linking libraries to the renderer.
Also there's no need to link the opengl libs to the opengl3 renderer when the glad extension loader is being used.
column21:
The variable yquake2RendererLinkerFlags is used to store the linker flags for opengl but the empty variable yquake2OpenGLLinkerFlags is used when linking libraries to the renderer.
Also there's no need to link the opengl libs to the opengl3 renderer when the glad extension loader is being used.

column13: Fix opengl linking for the renderers.

The variable yquake2RendererLinkerFlags is used to store the linker flags for opengl but the empty variable yquake2OpenGLLinkerFlags is used when linking libraries to the renderer.
Also there's no need to link the opengl libs to the opengl3 renderer when the glad extension loader is being used.

column20:
Due to a couple of issues on OSX the Makefile can be improved (along with bug fix in code that highlighted due to Makefile issues).

The filter seems to include an extra comma that causes an error in Make.
Homebrew does not install openal-soft completely due to OpenAL included in OSX.  Either set LD_LIBRARY_PATH to point to it or we can compile with rpath to point to it (and we assume location anyway).
Due to issues with setting LD_LIBRARY_PATH my first few tests failed to load the OpenAL library and causes an error when Ogg_Pause tries to stop the stream at end of first level in lift.  Make sure we test for OpenAL.

column21: We've just merged this by hand since it conflicted with the OS X timing fixes branch. Thank you :)
Cool, thank you.

Cool, that looks good. At least on a very first sight. It even works on the Raspberry PI 3. :) Of course, some questions arise:

What to do whith the cvars? Currently all render independent cvars are prefixed with gl_ and render specific cvars with gl1_ or gl3_. Moving the softrenderer into the gl_ namespace would be easiest but feels wrong. Staying with r_ complicates things. Moving the GL renderers back to r_ breaks existing configs...
It would be really nice if at least overbrightbits could be implemented into the softrenderer. It shouldn't be too hard, maybe the GL1 code could be used as a starting point. Some other features added to the GL renderers are support for tga textures and jpeg screenshots.

And of course the big question if we're able to maintain another renderer over the years to come.

Thank you.
@Yamagi I have changed code to use sw_mode for soft render, and also added logic for screenshots.
And have such known issues:

Code is used palette based colors so overbright will take little more time.
Also code does not have implementation for scale.
And code segfault with 2K resolution.


And of course the big question if we're able to maintain another render over the years to come.

I think we can disable soft render by default and user can enable when wants (same as SDL1.2).

So with this software render you're working on, will we finally be able to play on higher resolutions without crashing every time we jump in water? If I remember correctly, any resolution above 1152x864 will crash the game every time you submerge in water.
@iButane I have tried 1366x768 - looks as works without any crashes in softrender, but above 2k resolutions is crashed for sure.

The game will crash at resolutions above 1280x1024 when jumping into water with ref_soft.  I believe, but am not 100% on this, that there are some sizes that must be changed and that sezero may have solved this issue.  I will forward him this conversation.
I remember that MAXHEIGHT and MAXWIDTH must be changed, but if I recall from previous conversations with sezero there is still a fundamental limit of 2084.

About the crashes:  MAXWIDTH and MAXHEIGHT are important, and care
should be taken when changing (bumping) them.


be careful if you ever want to change MAXWIDTH: 12.20 fixed
point math used in R_ScanEdges() overflows at width 2048.


the screen warp code expects hardcoded 1600x1200 max resolution
instead of using the macros.


I'm attaching two patches here (you can git am them):


first one replaces some (long) casts on pointers with intptr_t,
which is needed for WIN64, because WIN64 is LLP64 and not LP64.


second one changes MAXHEIGHT back to 1200 (because I did a lazy
copy/paste), adds back MAXWIDTH as 1600, and adjusts the screen
warp code to use those macros as it was done in q1, so it would
not crash in water so long as your resolution is a legitimate
one: you should take care to filter your resolutions accordingly.


Additional note about horplus fov and softrender:  the changes
need implementing in r_misc.c:R_ViewChanged() and R_SetupFrame(),
and ref_soft needs notifying about horplus being in effect or
not.  See the changes in q2dos port I did for this; the relevant
commits should be these four:
https://bitbucket.org/neozeed/q2dos/commits/30b42a7c563cd51a138af739c7dd4d1563a61f28
https://bitbucket.org/neozeed/q2dos/commits/aba4a2dede0011839ffc04bb4d7f71e1422b8532
https://bitbucket.org/neozeed/q2dos/commits/3b0711a096a31da2e0102eb18e4ea5390cc85412
https://bitbucket.org/neozeed/q2dos/commits/928c763c67d34791b68670d0ec3cf87b21010d53
0001-replace-several-long-casts.txt
0002-sintable-size-warp-buffer-size.txt

@sezero  Thank you. Do you know exact line/state where value overflows? I like to support 2048+ resolutiions.
I am trying to get rid any harcoded values that can block of use bigger resolutions/textures or waste memmory in case 320*240 resolution, so am working on reallocate buffers on resolution change.

Do you know exact line/state where value overflows?

Really can't remember, sorry.

who needs true color in the SW renderer?
if people want the game to be pretty they can just use on of the OpenGL renderers
@DanielGibson Ok, so i  squashed all commits and you can review/check changes(If you like :-) ), code disabled by default.

Hey, that's very good work. I've tested a little bit and so far nearly everything seems to work. UI scaling, the overbright bit are looking very good, extremly high resolutions are running fine and even the annoying problem with water surfaces doesn't occure. :)
Just two small bugs:

If the videos are played in an widescreen window they're are placed in the middle and the surround background should be black. With the softrenderer that background is magenta. That's likely an "set everything to black" missing somewhere.
The brightness slider in the video menu is inversed.

There may be a problem with the vsync. The game holds 60hz just  perfectly but there seems to be some micro stuttering, like some frame are delayed for too long. But that may be an Xorg or driver problem on my side. I'll check that in the next few days and report back.
Otherwise I'm fine with merging that. One remaining question is what to do with the cvars. I have an idea how we could rewrite the cvars at config loading time. With such mechanism we could rename gl_* back to r_*. I'll to discuss that with @DanielGibson.
And you may add yourself to the credits in menu.c right below "Sander van Dijk". :)

@Yamagi

Gamma/brigness fixed
background cleaned up by minimal color in pallete
added self to credits

About vsync - i have not seted VSYNC flag before 60b4448 - i am not sure that it relly change anything. I have never seen fps > 30 for fullscreen except 320*240.

I'd vote for renaming all the r_* cvars back. They are named this way in all id software games and renaming them to gl_* is breaking an important tradition and engine inter-compatibility (or even with a renderer as you've noticed).
From the end user standpoint, say, I just downloaded Yamagi and started making maps, I need to set r_lightmap 1 to see if my lightmaps are looking good, or do r_showtris 1 to see if the compiler generated any garbage faces, or do r_fullbright 1 to check out the texturing in dark places. You get my point... Why should the user re-learn just for this specific engine?

I gave it another try and the vsync looks good now. I'm not quite sure if it was your change or just the fact that I'm on an machine with the Nvidia blob and not on my rather slow laptop. Nevertheless: Good work!
@Yamagi Thank you:-)

Hi,
I just tried to implement CMake support for the soft renderer and stumbled over a somewhat scary problem. There're some symbol collissions between the client and the new ref_soft.so: At least some of the symbols in vid.c (starting with line 438) are  defined in both the client and the ref_soft.so library, which symbol takes precendence is dependend on the linker flags. If the symbols in the client have higher precedence, the ref_soft.so calls back into the client as soon as one of these symbols is referenced for the first time. The function in the client tries to call the one in the ref_soft.so, but instead it calls itself. This results in an endless recursion until the stack overflows... So, can you rename the colliding symbols in ref_soft.so?
Thank you,
Yamagi
The CMake integration (and some other very small changes) can be found here: https://github.com/yquake2/yquake2/tree/softrenderer
@Yamagi fixed by rename to RE_*

And now it's merged. Thank's again. :) I'm going to disable the softrenderer by default until @DanielGibson  and I have renamed the renderer cvars. That'll happen some time after christmas, likely in early january. After that we'll ship it in the default install.

column13: Fix crash on Windows if MSAA is set to a value the driver doesn't support
column20:
(This has been lying around for almost 3 monts, totally forgot to merge this before..)
For some fucking reason, if you set an unsupported
SDL_GL_MULTISAMPLESAMPLES value on Windows (at least Win10 with Intel GPU
drivers, there 16 is unsupported), creating the Window and OpenGL context
will succeed, but you'll get Microsofts stupid GDI OpenGL software
implementation that only supports OpenGL 1.1.
Before these fixes, the GL3 renderer would just crash and the GL1 renderer
would fail to load, which caused the game to run in the background:
No Window, no Input, but sound was playing..
Now this problem should be handled properly and if initialization fails,
the rendering backend will be considered not working, and it will
try the gl1 backend next, and if that also fails it'll give up and exit
the game.
column21:
(This has been lying around for almost 3 monts, totally forgot to merge this before..)
For some fucking reason, if you set an unsupported
SDL_GL_MULTISAMPLESAMPLES value on Windows (at least Win10 with Intel GPU
drivers, there 16 is unsupported), creating the Window and OpenGL context
will succeed, but you'll get Microsofts stupid GDI OpenGL software
implementation that only supports OpenGL 1.1.
Before these fixes, the GL3 renderer would just crash and the GL1 renderer
would fail to load, which caused the game to run in the background:
No Window, no Input, but sound was playing..
Now this problem should be handled properly and if initialization fails,
the rendering backend will be considered not working, and it will
try the gl1 backend next, and if that also fails it'll give up and exit
the game.

column20:
Apparently something (possibly nvidia's driver) on some windows installations has some stupid application profile for quake2.exe that breaks mouse input if the console has been opened, see #257
The workaround is to rename quake2.exe to yquake2.exe and provide a wrapper quake2.exe that just calls the real one for backwards compatibility.

column20: Removed unused function and variables and added 'static' to local variables and functions.
column21:
Already tried that once and it doesn't work. We need to derive the millisecond counter from the microsecond counter, otherwise they diverge and the player sees subtile timing problems. And at my tests SDL_GetTicks() wasn't precise enough. I didn't look at the code back than but it seemed like SDL caches the value for some time and doesn't redetermine it at every call.
One well ment tip: Do yourself a favour and leave everything timing related alone. Quake IIs timing code is a bitch (sorry), even small changes can break it in very subtile and hard to notice ways. Those bugs are often even harder to debug. After literally tens of hours debugging and rethinking the code we're now in the comfortable situation that it works in all situations. Synchronous and asyncronos client, the network code against new and old server, the renderer with vsync enabled and disabled, on too slow CPUs or GPUs, broken GPU drivers (Hello AMD!), broken compositors, between all platforms, etc. It's just a big mess...

column20: Removed unused function and variables and added 'static' to local variables and functions.
column21:
As much as I love SDL, I'm against making the whole code depend on it heavily.
Right now, we (mostly?) only use at at the "edges" to the system (window handing, sound, ...), very few source files make any SDL calls - even the OpenGL backends only have one source file with SDL stuff each.
For the SW renderer this is different, and that's OK because SDL is its graphics API, but let's keep the generic code generic.
(But even in the SW renderer, please continue to use Sys_Milliseconds() so its view on time is consistent with the rest of the game)

column21:
I use this port for MP and it's great minus the slow downloads of skins, maps etc.
Would be nice to have faster http downloads when connecting to servers.

FreeBSD already has some special handling in the Minizip code. However not by me... And we likely need something similar for DragonFly, NetBSD, the Illumos family and so on. What about a more general approach: Define IOAPI_NO_64 unconditionally on all platforms except Linux and Windows? Even if the platform needs fopen64() for large file support it's very unlikely that someone really has a >2GB ZIP file with assets.
BSD switched to 64-bit offsets over 20 years ago (in BSD 4.4 or so).
My suggestion can be found in d6f9cf6. It works on FreeBSD and Linux, of course. Would be nice if anyone could test it on OpenBSD.
Works fine.
And merged to master. Thank you! :)

column13: Fix for vorbis/vorbisfile.h not found on macOS with CMake
column20:
My setup was, I installed the dependencies with homebrew as recommended in the yquake2 readme, created a build subdirectory in yquake2 and ran cmake .. -GXcode.
The CMake script was detecting OggVorbis but the  OGGVORBIS_INCLUDE_DIR variable was blank, and my compile was failing with an
/Users/ericwa/dev/yquake2/src/client/sound/ogg.c:38:10: fatal error: 'vorbis/vorbisfile.h' file not found
#include <vorbis/vorbisfile.h>

error.
Changing to VORBIS_INCLUDE_DIR instead of OGGVORBIS_INCLUDE_DIR (
which doesn't seem to be set in the FindOggVorbis.cmake) fixed the issue.
Tested on the Xcode and Unix Makefiles cmake generators, only on macOS 10.13.4
column21:

The CMake script was detecting OggVorbis but the  OGGVORBIS_INCLUDE_DIR variable was blank, and my compile was failing with an

point math used in R_ScanEdges() overflows at width 2048 !! */

sizeof(int) is 4 basically everywhere, including x86_64
sizeof(size_t) and sizeof(void*) is 8 on x86_64 (and 4 on 32bit x86)
sizeof(long) is 4 on x86 and windows x86_64 (x64) and 8 on x86_64 on Linux, *BSD, OSX etc
(=> don't use long)

because size_of(integer) == 8 on x86_64

NO, it is not. sizeof(int) is 4 on ILP32 systems, i.e. practically everywhere.
However sizeof(long) is 8 on LP64 systems, i.e. all unix, etc, (except for
win64 who obviously feel some sort of urge to be weird.)

Well Microsofts reasoning (and from someone who almost exclusively develops and uses Windows I don't agree on this) was that keep longs the same size as ints was to make it easier to recompile applications for x64.  Which fine, OK, but then it makes it harder when you want to port the same application to anything that is not Windows.  Grepping for long and unsigned long isn't the worst thing in the world, but ugh.

Just tested it, the water works well now at 1280x720 and 1680x1050 👍
[-pedantic] fix compilation waring about static array initialization
who cares, it works on all relevant compilers (and remember many compilers are not supported because we reequire C99 VLAs anyway)..  fixing code to work with -Wpedantic is a waste of time, IMHO
I can tell you many stories about pedantic warnings and pedantic bugs.

sizeof(int) is 4 basically everywhere, including x86_64

yep, my mistake. I also replaced use "integer" to shift20_t(already merged code) - so type can be changed in one place.
"-pedantic" fixes is useful in one case - we can search typos in code.
I also added "Unreal kernel filtering" with separate flag, from http://fabiensanglard.net/quake2/quake2_software_renderer.php
@DanielGibson @Yamagi Could you please review changes?

This looks very, very good. I'm impressed how you care for code quality. I've always been the pedantic type of developer and even after more than 10 years I'm still disgusted by Quake2s code... I'm totally fine with merging this if @DanielGibson has no objections.
For the bigger plan: In the last weeks I've removed SDL 1.2 and refactored the client <-> renderer interaction. The soft renderer is still special but that shouldn't be a problem as long there's only one renderer using the SDL Renderer interface. And I don't thing that we'll ever add another soft renderer. Yesterday I've finally replaced the libvorbis dependencies with the stb_vorbis single header library. I'm currently pondering if I could and should do the same with zlib, to get rid of all statically linked dependencies. After that I'll wait 2 or 3 weeks for bug reports and then do the next release, 7.30. Likely at the end of august or in early september.

Hmm... soft -> gl and gl -> soft are working on my desktop with FreeBSD and Nvidia. But I see the same problems as you on the laptop with Linux and Intel.
One problem is that SWimp_Shutdown() calls SDL_Quit*(). That's clearly wrong, SDL is now initialized and deinitialized by vid.c. The problem with the duplicate window is somewhat more tricky. I've missed a call to ShutdownGraphics() in GLimp_Shutdown() but that's not enough. We need  to destroy the window at renderer shutdown by calling ShutdownGraphics() from VID_ShutdownRenderer(). With that the window handling works but the softrenderer doesn't show anything. So we likely need to reset SDLs internal GL state when the GL renderers are shutting down. And tada it work.
The code (more or less untested!) can be found here: https://github.com/yquake2/yquake2/tree/renderswitch This is of course still hacky. In theory we would need a swimp_sdl.c at client side and vid.c needs to track if GL or soft renderer is running. But that's a lot of work. Maybe for cold winter evenings. :)
Renaming both sw_texture_filtering and gl_anisotropic to r_anisotropic is a good idea. You need to add them to the replacement list in cvar.c, otherwise older config will break.

Cool, i will check.
Also about "another soft renderer." :-) We also can have full color render (i suppose it can share 50% of code from current soft render) and vulkan render. Only because we can....

If we want another soft renderer 'just because we can' we'll need a swimp_sdl.c to coordinate between them.
In the old SDL 1.2 world there was no real distinction between the window and the GL state. When SDL 2.0 arrived we hacked the code to support the old SDL 1.2 way and the newly introduced window <-> state seperation. In the last weeks I've removed SDL 1.2 support, put the window handling in the client and the GL state handling in the renderer. Having the state handled by the renderer saves a lot calls between client and renderer. Additionally I've cleaned up some historical dept like the SDL reinitialization at vid_restart.
This is somewhat complicated by the missuse of vid_fullscreen. The client and all renderers set the vid_fullscreen cvar to 'modified' to communicate changes to the renderer configuration, triggering a vid_restart.
TL;DR: In theory the soft renderer needs to follow the changes made to the GL renderer. Because it worked / works I haven't done it.
I'm still fine with this. Let's @DanielGibson have a look. I'll merge it if he has no objections.
Merged. Thank you. My window handling fixes will follow shortly.

Thank you, @Yamagi i have pushed several commits 1c1bf1e render_speedup_review for reuse GLimp_InitGraphics in SoftRender, its not fully tested and maybe has some issues in render change, but soft->gl3->gl1->gl3->soft and change resolution are worked by first look.
Also canbe issues with color space on BIG_ENDIAN devices.
I just had a short look into that branch. That looks much better than the current approach and should solve most if not all window handling problems. @DanielGibson, can you take another look? :)

@Yamagi @DanielGibson I have created separate #317 for this changes, also i have removed use of SDLSurface as we does not need such and changed texture format back as previous format rendered twice faster.

column21:
Ok, thanks!
On the one hand it would be nice if macOS users could build YQ2 as easily as possible, but the problem with Xcode project files is that neither Yamagi nor me have a Mac, and thus we can't adjust those projects when needed (if we add or rename a file that needs to be compiled etc).
With CMake we don't have those problems, we can adapt CMakelists.txt accordingly and make sure it still builds at least on Linux/BSD/Windows, so if we have a working CMake setup for Mac once it's unlikely to break in a major way.
By the way, we recently moved some files around (see current master) when removing SDL1.2 and doing related cleanups; we also removed dependencies on zlib and libogg and libvorbis(file) by using miniz and stb_vorbis.h - this should make building on Mac even easier. I think the only dependencies apart from the standard C and system headers (incl. OpenGL) are SDL2 and OpenAL now.

column20:
Hi,
'GREATER_EQUAL' was introduced in CMake 3.7:
https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.7/release/3.7.html#commands
CMakeList.txt states that minimum required version of CMake is 3.0. So please use 'GREATER' instead of 'GREATER_EQUAL'.
Please also note, that Ubuntu 16.04 has CMake 3.5, so using 'GREATER_EQUAL' will break build process for this platform.
Best regards,

column20: When hosting or joining a server via a IPV6 address no connection can be made. This is because of the ipv6 address '::' which should be '::1'. This PR fixes this mistake.

column20: When hosting or joining a server via a IPV6 address no connection can be made. This is because of the ipv6 address '::' which should be '::1'. This PR fixes this mistake.
column21:
I don't think this is correct.
::1 is the equivalent of 127.0.0.1, so it's a loopback-address, only reachable from the same machine, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Localhost
:: is the equivalent of 0.0.0.0, so it's the unspecified address, and listening on that address means "accept connections on all network interfaces and all their addresses", see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv6_address#Unspecified_address
So it should be correct to listen on :: (and not ::1) here.

column20:
r1q2 has a neat feature: transparent server-side map entity replacement, this is, the loading of external files ending in .override (i.e. base2.bsp.override) which adds or change entities to a map depending on the gamemode on the server. Previously, these files ended in .ent (i.e. base2.ent). These files are plain text files containing the entities present in a map.
For example, you want to play CTF on the map base2, but found that the map lacks the flags and spawnpoints, so you use these .override files in order to add CTF support to it by way of adding the flags, spawnpoints and other necessary entities.

Previously, these files ended in .ent (i.e. base2.ent). These files are plain text files containing the entities present in a map.
For example, you want to play CTF on the map base2, but found that the map lacks the flags and spawnpoints, so you use these .override files in order to add CTF support to it by way of adding the flags, spawnpoints and other necessary entities.

column20: .override files are files containing the entities on a map (i.e. base2.override). It's usually used for entity manipulation (i.e. adding CTF support to a non-CTF map, complete with weapon/item balance) without touching the original map.

column13: Minor bug-fixes: Case-insensitive file loading & Rogue dmflags display
column20:
I noticed these issues while making some changes for CTF in the "Start Server" menu for myself:

Case-insensitivity isn't working for directly loading files when YQ2 is located in a directory tree with capitalization (when it is also executed from a different directory than where it resides).
It looks like there's a typo in the code that would prevent the Rogue dmflags from displaying in the menu.  (I don't have the mission pack to verify that, though.)

Also, let me know if you'd be interested in adding the CTF-specific game options to the "Start Server" menu and "dmflags" menu, and I'll send those through.

column13: Add support for CTF options to "start network server" menu.
column20:
Allow numeric input of "capturelimit" cvar and toggling of CTF dmflags via menu system as follows:

"start network server" menu


Remove "rules" selection from "start network server" menu.  (No coop support in CTF; defaults to deathmatch.)
Add input box for "capturelimit."


"deathmatch flags" menu


Remove flags ignored in CTF: "teamplay" & "friendly fire."
Add toggling of "force join," "armor protect," and "no techs" dmflags.

Existing var names & dmflag definitions for Rogue support were re-used since they're otherwise idle in CTF.

column21:
The retexturing support for the soft renderer looks good and will be merged. The only question is if it would make sense to combine gl_retexturing and sw_retexturing into r_retexturing. The point is, that it should be enabled by default for the GL renderers, but it's likely a better idea to keep it disabled by default for the soft renderer.
But the cppcheck stuf... I don't know. Okay, most if not all changes look correct. On the other hand they introduce unnecessary churn. They diverge the code even more from other clients and baseq2 from the addons. And they have a little chance to introduce new bugs. So maybe it's better to leave things as they are and live with the fact that Quake II is rather crappy.

column13: Fixed menu code to correctly parse maps.lst file.
column20:
While working on my personal project using your quake 2 fork I noticed issues parsing my map.lst file, I had to change the line terminator from \r to \n. Not sure if there are other types of map.lst files with a different format to them. Perhaps the better solution would be using || and testing for both conditions.
The original code gave me an No maps in maps.lst error.
My maps.lst file contents are the following:
q2dm1 "The Edge"
q2dm2 "Tokay's Towers" 
q2dm3 "The Frag Pipe" 
q2dm4 "Lost Hallways"
q2dm5 "The Pits"
q2dm6 "Lava Tomb"
q2dm7 "The Slimy Place"
q2dm8 "WareHouse"

Thanks for the cleaned up Quake 2 code 👍 !

column21:
Looks good to me, this way it should work with both Unix-style \n and windows-style \r\n (no one cares about MacOS classic just \r anymore)
Testing both conditions with || wouldn't work: if the file has windows line endings - \r\n - each line would be counted twice.
However, this reminds me of one thing: The last line won't be counted this way, unless it's followed by newline (=> there is an empty line below it).
Maybe that should be fixed as well..

  stuff/cmake/modules/FindSDL2.cmake:173 (FIND_PACKAGE_HANDLE_STANDARD_ARGS)

column21:
The general problem with Yamagi Quake II itself and all 3 addons  on Windows is, that the code does not compile with MSVC. At least not without ugly hacks. It uses several smaller C99 features and parts of the code (the old GL1 renderer) make excessive use of VLAs. The release builds are currently build with gcc in an MSYS2 environment. It may be possible to use a native clang instead, but I never had the patients to figure that out.
Regarding cmake and SDL2: I really don't know. The CMakeLists.txt works on FreeBSD, Linux and MacOS, so it should also work on Windows. But I've never tried it and I have no clue what the SDL2 module does to find the library. It look like there aren't search pathes for Windows in it - https://github.com/yquake2/yquake2/blob/master/stuff/cmake/modules/FindSDL2.cmake
Btw., q2vkpt is very nice. Keep up the good work! :)

column20:
In order to switch weapons in a convenient way on a controller one needs a better mechanism in Quake 2 to do so because of the limited number of buttons a controller.
This change consists of 2 changes:

Add a couple of bindings in the config.cfg (HAT_LEFT...HAT_DOWN for first 4 weapons to adress, one binding for the "selector key" (JOY6 on the PS4 controller on a retropie, the top right shoulder button).
Support in Quake 2 to let the user press "selector key" + HAT_LEFT...HAT_DOWN to reach 4 more weapons. The selector key should also be rebindable from the "control settings" in the GUI.

My solution now also introduces 4 new cvars, "weaponselector_weapon1"..."weaponselector_weapon4" for the weapons that can be reached through "selector key" + HAT_LEFT...HAT_DOWN. This will make it possible to use this for mods as well as the cvars could be setup in the config.cfg of the mod if you have weapons with new names.

I haven't gotten around to look at the code more closely, but the general approach of +weaponselector sounds reasonable and being able to bind those combinations (instead of hardcoding the weapon names) is a good idea as well!
I wonder if this could be generalized a bit further so "weaponselector button" + "any known joystick button/hat direction" can behave like a logical key/button that can be bound directly? So e.g. in addition to K_HAT_UP we'd have K_HAT_UP_WEAPSEL (or whatever name), same for K_JOY*
Just a random idea, as I said I haven't looked closely at the code yet and don't know if it's feasible.

column21:
Hi Daniel (Guessing this is your name :)
I like that idea, I think the Id team for sure would have made it like that if there were people playing with controllers back in those days. It would be cool to be able to say  'bind K_HAT_UP + K_JOY6 "use Grenade Launcher"'. It probably is a bit more work though cause I guess the parser would need to be able to understand it and some generalized form of it supported in cl_keyboard.c
I might try and have a look at it, but I think this solution is still probably a good leg-up for most players out there using example the retropie/retroarch + controller and a dual-stick controller like the ps4 controller or xbox controller. It is pretty standard in FPS-like game to choose weapon using these keys on a controller at least on the PS4.
Trying to dive into your doom3 port as well, would be awesome to bring that to the say the retropie. But might prove to be a bit to big of a challenge since Im guessing it will need a opengl es 2.0 port and Im just one guy already pushing 40h at my pay-for-the-food-and-rent job :)

Hi XD,
Personally, I was never a fan of this weapon wheel selector. To often I ended up choosing the wrong weapon and it was annoying to have to shift my focus from trying to aim at the bad guys to select the weapon I wanted. I prefer a solution where it is mapped to one button or one button + some other button. It could be cool to show which weapon is assigned to which button on the HUD though, especially if you press down a button, so you can easily see which button maps to which key.

column21:
It could be cool to show which weapon is assigned to which button on the HUD though, especially if you press down a button, so you can easily see which button maps to which key.

That may not be impossible, but hard to implement. The input stuff is split between the renderer and the client, the HUD is generated in the game and send through the server (over the network) to the client. For such display the HUD calls must be intercepted and altered in the client, without breaking mods and the like.

column21:
Hi,
I've re-worked the solution a bit more. I chosed to go with a cvar solution to be able to map the alternative keys and add an additional menu "customize controls alt function" (maybe the name should change - anyone got a better one?) where you can map the extra keys. The reason I choose to store it cvars is simply because it seemed like to much of a mess to try and hitch on to the bind logic.
The menu sends a "bind KEY "do this thing" using Com_sprintf in Keys_MenuKey. The "bind" command in turn is tied to char *keybindings (cl_keyboard.c). So to support using bind, I would need to either expand the keybindings entry and re-write all functions that look into that (which is quite
intricate if one just freetext search keybindings and see all the code that peeks and pokes at this data).
I just think it introduces to much of a risk for bugs/unexpected behaviour to grant updating the "bind" code. If not updating the "bind" code I would need to introduce a new command and use that especially for this thing, which did not feel right either. Hence, I choose to use cvars and use the same infrastructure that the menu uses for binding keys (Com_sprintf, but sending a "set weaponblahblah_key_X "SOME KEY") and then I use the same cvars in cl_keyboard.c to figure out what button combination equals what action. This way, it can also be set in .cfg file on startup directly.
Any thoughts on this one? I want to clean it up a bit. Perhaps change name from weaponselector to "alternate" or something like that and try to add support for 3 more things I think might be nice to reach using the "alternate" key - inventory (previous, next, use).
I've already checked in this change so you can have a look at it and see if you think this is a sufficent solution though. And weigh in on the added menu, if you like that idea or not.
I did this all under a bit of a fever and headache but I just could'nt keep away - let me know if something looks weird or is just not proper.
Cheers
/Jimmie

column13: Allow second layer of keybindings for controllers, refs #387
column20:
There's an "enable alt joy keys" command now. If a key is bound to that
command, all joystick buttons (incl. hat and triggers) are turned from
K_JOYx into K_JOYx_ALT, which allows two keybindings on the same key,
one with the altselector pressed and one without.
If there's no keybinding for K_JOYx_ALT, it will use the binding for
just K_JOYx as a fallback (if it exists).
This is especially handy to create direct bindings for all the weapons
on the (limited amount of) Joystick buttons.
This is inspired by #387 / #388

column13: Allow second layer of keybindings for controllers, refs #387
column20:
There's an "enable alt joy keys" command now. If a key is bound to that
command, all joystick buttons (incl. hat and triggers) are turned from
K_JOYx into K_JOYx_ALT, which allows two keybindings on the same key,
one with the altselector pressed and one without.
If there's no keybinding for K_JOYx_ALT, it will use the binding for
just K_JOYx as a fallback (if it exists).
This is especially handy to create direct bindings for all the weapons
on the (limited amount of) Joystick buttons.
This is inspired by #387 / #388
column21:
Hi Daniel,
Just got home and tested it from the main repo and it works beautifully :)
Me personally I'm happy with this fix. A menu option would of course be a nice-to-have but it might be a bit more work, especially if we want to support mods with other weapon names in it.
As for the common retropie user, I think most will be happy if there is a mapping for the most common controllers (ps4 + xbox controller) and an wiki-entry informing about this.
For the PS4 which I have tested it on this setting works pretty well:
(I'm trying to reach out to the retropie repo owners to push an update for this)
bind JOY6 "+joyaltselector"
bind HAT_LEFT "use Shotgun"
bind HAT_UP "use Super Shotgun"
bind HAT_RIGHT "use Machinegun"
bind HAT_DOWN "use Chaingun"
bind HAT_LEFT_ALT "use Grenade Launcher"
bind HAT_UP_ALT "use Rocket Launcher"
bind HAT_RIGHT_ALT "use HyperBlaster"
bind HAT_DOWN_ALT "use Railgun"
If everyone is ok with this fix I guess I can remove my pull-request?
/Jimmie

column13: Make gl3 fast with AMDs Windows drivers
column20:
Seems like AMDs Windows driver doesn't like it when we call glBufferData() a lot (other drivers, incl. Intels and, IIRC, the AMD legacy driver used for the Radeon HD 6850 don't seem to care as much).
Even on an i7-4771 with a Radeon RX 580 I couldn't get stable 60fps on Windows without this workaround (the open source Linux driver is ok).
The be enabled/disabled with the gl3_usebigvbo CVar; by default it's -1 which means "enable if AMD driver is detected".
Enabling it when using a nvidia GPU with their proprietary drivers reduces the performance to 1/3 of the fps we get without it, so it indeed needs to be conditional...
So yeah, this is our first GPU-vendor specific workaround :-/
I'm not 100% sure about the code yet, I especially wonder if I should add some padding between the data in the VBO of consecutive calls to GL3_BufferAndDraw3D()..

This resolves a couple issues, allowing all targets to be successfully built for Windows using CMake.
I'm assuming that SDL is linked with q2ded on Windows for Unicode command line support. Would it be worth using wmain directly in order to remove that dependency?

column21:
And merged, thank you. :)
SDL_main is mainly used for UTF-8 command line arguments, yes. And the dedicated server needs to be able to parse command line arguments with non-ascii chars in it. Besides that we try to minimize the differences between the full client and the dedicated server. So let's keep things as they are.

column13: Allow scrolling with mouse in console
column20:
Scroll functionality for both the mouse wheel and buttons 4 & 5 was already implemented in Key_Console(). However, those keycodes never reached that function as they were not declared in consolekeys.
Once that issue was fixed another appeared. If those keycodes were unbound, warning messages would then appear in instances where the console was technically open but cls.key_dest was not set to key_console (e.g. fullscreen console).
In order to fix this unbound key warnings now only print when in-game. This is the only time when the warnings are actually useful as Con_DrawNotify() is only called during gameplay.

column20:
This pull request adds an option to the "VIDEO" menu that allows you to specify which display/monitor you want the game to run on, and can be seen in the screenshot.

If this option is not desired, please feel free to disregard this pull request.
This adds a new archived Cvar "vid_displayindex" which the video menu sets and signals a restart with the "restart" qboolean in ApplyChanges()
Extra Notes:
The last_position_x and last_position_y variables don't actually seem to be used, though the window position is still stored in them.
I have a habit of adding extra spaces around parenthesis, and I notice I still accidentally did that, but if you prefer I conform to the no-spaces coding style, I can throw that in an extra commit.
If you have any other questions/comments/concerns, please let me know.

column21: Cool, good work. :)

Hi,
this breaks the menu. Not if it's opened while in game, but right after the game is started. The whole menu flickers and shows 'interlacing' artifacts.
the bug looks like this:

Thank you.
I can't reproduce issue in the stable way. I have seen such only one time. I have reverted last commit related to 2d textures damage. Last commit should improve check in menus and not critical to game mode.
@DanielGibson, @Yamagi  Could you recheck? Revert should fix issue.
I will recheck damage code and maybe create new PR or send as part of other PR.
I just gave it a try and I'm still seeing the issue.
Even with clean config. It seems to get worse when increasing the resolution. With 640x480 it's hard to notice, with 2560x1440 the menu is completely broken.

Issue looks as video driver specific behaviour logic related to partial textures update. I don't have other ideas for now.
@Yamagi Could you check 50f1526 now? I have reverted logic for search buffer difference end and use forced full buffer update be default.
I can confirm that 50f1526 is working for me :)
Can I merge it or do you want to do some other changes?

I have found reason of artifacts, it was related to partial update render from texture. As result fps change is not so impressive something like 27.1->29.2..30.7 instead 33+. Artifacts related to places where detected no change in current frame. By some reason artifact never appear in top of screen(change/flush from center to screen bottom), but for sure I have deleted whole part of partial update(SDL_RenderCopy(renderer, texture, &copy_rect, &copy_rect);).
@Yamagi @DanielGibson If you see no artifacts with new code, code can be merged.
And merged. Thank you. :)

column20:
Save current player position and compare with a position in the previous
frame, if position is same refresh only changed rectangle in zbuffer.
zBuffer can be damaged by models, particles and static transparent spans.
zBuffer damage is not useful for the screen refresh minimize for now,
as result of explosion can change texture light value.
Add logic for dump current position in world.
remove screen flush after after a palette change, fixes issue with black screen on new game after show the introduction video

column13: Full bugfix for monsters not fighting parasites
column20: I noticed the bugfix to asdress #440 was incomplete. This pull request completes it by setting the parasite's viewheight to 16, ensuring traces don't shoot over its bbox. I also added if (!self->viewheight) checks to swimmonster and flymonster as well for consistency with walkmonster.

column13: Fix for insane marines not always playing pain sounds
column20: This was a little thing partially caused by the change in sound prioritization. Insane marines will no longer scream or moan for 1 second after taking damage. To my knowledge the insane marines are the only enemy type in the game who need this special handling of sound priority. This also fixes the sound issue on nightmare difficulty, since they don't go into pain frames they constantly moan and scream which frequently would cut off the pain sound. I will also add pull requests for xatrix and rogue to address this there.

column13: Triggered spawned monsters use path_corner correctly
column20:
This pull request addresses issue #458.
Long story short, it was caused by triggered spawn monsters calling monster_start_go() twice. First during initial spawn and then again when they are spawned by being triggered. The first call works correctly but the second call actually clears the target and sets the monster to stand still.
I fixed this by making triggered spawn monsters only call monster_start_go() once - when they get triggered.
You can use the security.ent test file from the bug report to see that when you pick up the shotgun, the triggered guard moves to his marker like the other guard does.
column21:
This pull request addresses issue #458.
Long story short, it was caused by triggered spawn monsters calling monster_start_go() twice. First during initial spawn and then again when they are spawned by being triggered. The first call works correctly but the second call actually clears the target and sets the monster to stand still.
I fixed this by making triggered spawn monsters only call monster_start_go() once - when they get triggered.
You can use the security.ent test file from the bug report to see that when you pick up the shotgun, the triggered guard moves to his marker like the other guard does.

A documentation entry for coop_baseq2 would be very welcome. We try to document all cvars that we changed or added. Not a problem here, but good to know: We've got an alias mechanism for renamed cvars. The old and new name can be added to replacements array in cvar.c and it just works.

column13: Added gl1_particle_use_pointparams to avoid the point parameters rendering path
column20:
ref_gl1 renders points weirdly on my machine. Way too big, and square.
After trying to work out why for an hour or so I just forced it to use R_DrawParticles2() regardless of point parameters support, which renders them correctly. I added gl1_particle_use_pointparms to make it slightly cleaner, but it's still quite hacky...
Someone with more experience can likely work out why R_DrawParticles() wasn't behaving, and point me to a real fix, which would be appreciated.

column13: Fix for insane marines not firing deathtarget right away
column20:
Fixes bug #495. As detailed in the comments, this was caused by using the delay struct member for storing data specific to the insane-marines, when in fact it is a generally used value by G_UseTargets.
I fixed it by using a different struct member, fly_sound_debounce_time, this time making absolutely sure there won't be any interference. This struct member is only stored and referenced in one place in the code and only by clients, so interference by the insane marines code is impossible. I added a comment in local.h to explicitly state this new use case for the struct member.

column21:
Big thanks to @kondrak for initial porting to Vulkan.
Known issues:

checked only on the last debian testing with vulkan implementation from mesa
one file compiled by g++ instead gcc(Vulkan memory allocation),
retexturing use resolution from pcx files instead real file dimensions from high resolution file
open menu sometime broke rendering, looks like it related to run R_EndWorldRenderpass in wrong time, vkQuake has separate callback for R_EndWorldRenderpass, that does not exists in yquake.
maybe something else....

column21: Regarding R_EndWorldRenderpass - in vkQuake2, each time a popup appeared in the menu (when pinging servers, trying to refresh lists etc.) it caused the OpenGL path to exit prematurely - this didn't work with Vulkan, since the exit path did not submit all the data correctly, hence that function was introduced.
