column21:
Good morning,
it's nice to wake up and find something like this in the mailbox. Of course I haven't had a chance to take a deeper look, I just played through base1. First let me make clear, that I'm not against merging this. But before we can consider that some things needs to be ensured:

You've already linked to #373. @DanielGibson already wrote there, that neither he nor me have any knowledge about Vulkan. While it would be a nice project to read into it, hack a little bit around, etc. we currently don't have the time to do that. We aren't students anymore, we've got daytime jobs, families and other projects. Therefore it's inevitable that someone with Vulkan knowledge is willing to maintain this renderer. Work through bug report, analyse and fix the bugs, chase changes in GPU driver and the Vulkan SDK if necessary... More or less the same as we did for the software renderer.
There're likely some things that needs to be ruled out before we can merge it. It needs documentation, compiling the code with gcc9 gave some warnings, the gamma scale is the wrong way round (in the OpenGL renderers higher values are brighter, with the Vulkan renderer higher values are darker), typing disconnect into the console freezes the renderer... That are all fixable problems, but they need to be solved.

On a bigger scale the big question is if Vulkan is really the way to go or if it would be better to use something like https://github.com/bkaradzic/bgfx. With that we would get Vulkan, DirectX, Metal and WebGL by doing all the work involved with adding and maintaining a renderer only once.

column21:
So many helping hands. That's nice to see. :) What about something like this:

Fix the gamma (likely something like vid_gamma->value * -1 missing somewhere), fix the renderer hanging after disconnect (start a game with map base1, disconnect from it with disconnect and the renderer freezes) and update this pull request with the changes.
We merge the renderer into a feature branch and provide official test build. The test builds will be linked on the homepage. Fix upcoming bugs (I don't think that there will be many since the major part code was already tested in vkQ2), enhance the renderer API as needed (there aren't any out of tree consumers anyways) and write documentation.
After 3 to 6 month, when it's ready, it's merged into master and released as YQ2 8.0.

column21: I think that'll depend on the GPU driver. GPUs with crappy OpenGL drivers - for example the Windows driver for GCN Radeons - will likely see an improvement. GPUs with good OpenGL drivers won't, because they were already running at the hardware limit or YQ2s internal 999 FPS cap.

column21:
Hi,
thank you for your continued efforts. Let's start with some general comments:

Reviewing is much easier if the pull request / review request has only the relevant commits and not unrelated stuff. It would be really helpfull if rebasing / merging commits from master into the feature branch and actual changes can be kept separate.
From my experience it is a good idea to avoid unnecessary changes to the upstream code, it just makes merging future changes harder.
Does the Vulkan renderer really need the texture resizing stuff? Can't the textures just uploaded as they are? If I remember right the resizing code was only to support very early GPUs that required power of two textures. And is the STB resize code suited for Quake IIs low res textured, doesn't it change the look on such old GPUs if the textures are resized with a better algorithm? Doesn't a better algorithm require more CPU power?

Regarding the menu pop-ups: It's working now, but is it really a good idea to enter the renderer and abort the frame by returning early? Who not just adding a new function to the render API. There aren't any 3rd party renderers anyways, as far as I know.

column20:
build: Let users pass in their own CFLAGS, CPPFLAGS, LDFLAGS
There is a widely-used convention that CFLAGS, CPPFLAGS and LDFLAGS are
set by the user (or packaging system) when building software,
defaulting to empty: in Autotools terminology they are said to be
"reserved for the user". Linux distributions use this to provide
globally-used compiler flags, for example enabling enabling various
hardening features.
These are conventionally placed on the compiler command-line after the
build system's choice of CFLAGS and LDFLAGS, so that they can override
the build system's defaults. For example, when the Debian packaging
toolchain is told to build a package without optimization for debugging,
it includes -O0 in CFLAGS. This would not be effective in previous
versions of yquake2, which hard-code -O2.
Loosely based on a patch by Fabian Greffrath, which we have been applying
in Debian for several years.


build: Add an option to turn off RPATHs
When distributions like Debian build binaries that are going to use the
standard system-wide libraries in directories that are searched by
default, it's undesired to have a RPATH that makes the library search
behaviour less predictable. Continue to set the RPATH by default, for
use in portable binaries, but provide an off-switch.
Based on a patch by Fabian Greffrath, which we have been applying in
Debian for several years.

column21:
Loosely based on a patch by Fabian Greffrath, which we have been applying in Debian for several years.

In the previous patch we changed all the CFLAGS := to CFLAGS +=, but I think this one is better, because it gets the precedence right: if yquake2's default is -O2, and the user or packaging system that is installing it asks for -O0 or -Og because they are trying to debug it, we want the -O0 to win.

column21:
Also, looking at the changed code, it seems like CFLAGS is not used at all but has been replaced with YQ2_CFLAGS - am I missing something or does this mean that in fact the users CFLAGS don't have any effect?

I think you didn't spot the bit where CFLAGS and CPPFLAGS are appended to YQ2_CFLAGS, and CFLAGS and LDFLAGS are appended to YQ2_LDFLAGS (see the nearby comment for why it isn't the obvious 1:1 mapping).

I'm a bit afraid of letting the user set (systemwide, default?) compilerflags - if they feel clever and set -O3 or even -ffast-math shit might break.

If people are feeling clever, they're going to break it anyway. This setup matches how the compiler flags are normally handled in Autotools (always), Meson (always), and CMake (with -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=none).
The typical use of this in distributions is for packaging infrastructure (dpkg-buildflags or RPM macros) to build everything with debug symbols (-g), a conservative optimization level (-O2 or -O0 depending whether an unoptimized build was requested), and add security-hardening options like stack-protector and PIE.
Would it help if I wrapped it like this?
ifeq ($(WITH_COMPILER_FLAGS), yes)
# Take compiler flags from the environment. If you enable this, any broken
# builds that result are entirely your responsibility.
YQ2_CFLAGS += $(CPPFLAGS) $(CFLAGS)
(etc.)
endif

Or I could re-word the commit message and/or comments to phrase it in terms of distro compiler flags?

column21:
If people use -ffast-math and it breaks, that's because -ffast-math violates the C standard - which obviously is a bad idea to do in codebases that aren't expecting it. I realise the name of the option is rather a trap, because it sounds like such a good thing ("of course I want mathematics to be fast, this is a game engine!") - so perhaps something like this would make sense?
#ifdef __FAST_MATH__
#error gcc -ffast-math does not follow IEEE/ISO specifications and is not supported
#endif

column21:
Hi,
I've just pushed several commit into the branch cflags. They:

Make the base CFLAGS and LDFLAGS overrideable
Make sure that required compiler and linker flags are passed
Some general cleanup, mostly for Windows

They're here: https://github.com/yquake2/yquake2/commits/cflags
Instead of renaming CFLAGS and LDFLAGS and appending the environment to them, both base CFLAGS and LDFLAGS can be overridden by the environment. They're the first flags passed to the compiler and linker, thus they shouldn't be able to override required options. At least clang on FreeBSD is last option serves.

both base CFLAGS and LDFLAGS can be overridden by the environment. They're the first flags passed to the compiler and linker, thus they shouldn't be able to override required options.

I think that's correct on all reasonable platforms, yes.

column20:
build: Let users pass in their own CFLAGS, CPPFLAGS, LDFLAGS
There is a widely-used convention that CFLAGS, CPPFLAGS and LDFLAGS are
set by the user (or packaging system) when building software,
defaulting to empty: in Autotools terminology they are said to be
"reserved for the user". Linux distributions use this to provide
globally-used compiler flags, for example enabling enabling various
hardening features.
These are conventionally placed on the compiler command-line after the
build system's choice of CFLAGS and LDFLAGS, so that they can override
the build system's defaults. For example, when the Debian packaging
toolchain is told to build a package without optimization for debugging,
it includes -O0 in CFLAGS. This would not be effective in previous
versions of yquake2, which hard-code -O2.
Loosely based on a patch by Fabian Greffrath, which we have been applying
in Debian for several years.


build: Add an option to turn off RPATHs
When distributions like Debian build binaries that are going to use the
standard system-wide libraries in directories that are searched by
default, it's undesired to have a RPATH that makes the library search
behaviour less predictable. Continue to set the RPATH by default, for
use in portable binaries, but provide an off-switch.
Based on a patch by Fabian Greffrath, which we have been applying in
Debian for several years.
column21: I've pushed a commit that adds the WITH_RPATH option back. If it's set to no the RPATH to $ORIGIN/lib is ommitted and WITH_SYSTEMWIDE cannot be set to yes.

column21:
If it's set to no the RPATH to $ORIGIN/lib is ommitted

Great!

and WITH_SYSTEMWIDE cannot be set to yes

Is there a reason why not? WITH_SYSTEMWIDE but no RPATH is the configuration we use in Debian, and if the Debian package doesn't count as a system-wide installation, I don't know what is.
We put the quake2 and q2ded executables in /usr/lib/yamagi-quake2, the native-code (architecture-dependent) game modules in /usr/lib/yamagi-quake2/baseq2/game.so and so on, and the architecture-independent assets (pak files, videos, music) in /usr/share/games/quake2. I think that's in line with what you recommend in 070_packaging.md?
Unless I'm missing some secondary function, the RPATH is only needed if you are linking the game executable to shared libraries (SDL, libcurl etc.) in a non-standard location, for example bundled with yquake2. That's likely to be something you'd want to do if you are shipping a generic Linux binary designed to be portable between distributions, but the Debian package only needs to run on Debian, and gets all its shared libraries from the default library search path.
If I understand correctly, game.so is searched in the game search path (which includes the directory the executable is in) and passed to dlopen as an absolute path, and the refresher/renderer modules like ref_gl3.so are searched in the executable's directory and passed to dlopen as an absolute path, so it's unnecessary for the directory that contains them to appear in the RPATH (unless it also contains bundled libraries, which, again, distro packages don't).

column21:
WITH_SYSTEMWIDE but no RPATH is the configuration we use in Debian

More specifically, WITH_SYSTEMWIDE has two effects: it adds the RPATH ($(WITH_SYSTEMDIR)/lib or /usr/share/games/quake2/lib) for shared libraries, and it defines -DSYSTEMWIDE, which makes the engine look in SYSTEMDIR or /usr/share/games/quake2 for assets.
In the Debian package we want to get the assets from their system-wide location, but the RPATH is unnecessary and doesn't really make sense (we wouldn't install architecture-dependent native-code under /usr/share anyway).

column21:
I've tried applying the cflags branch to the yquake2 Debian package.
The general technique works fine for the pattern where you build like this:
CFLAGS="-Og -g" LDFLAGS="-Wl,--as-needed" make

or equivalently
export CFLAGS="-Og -g" LDFLAGS="-Wl,--as-needed"
make

However, it doesn't work for the case where you pass these variables as arguments to make, which is also a fairly common approach:
make CFLAGS="-Og -g" LDFLAGS="-Wl,--as-needed"

because in that case, the variables are completely overridden, ignoring any += (at least, that's the case with GNU make - I haven't tried *BSD make).
If you want that last pattern to work, I think the only alternative to using separate variables would be to use the syntax override CFLAGS += -fwrapv for the things you need to force, but I think that might be a feature that only exists in GNU make. Is the Makefile intended to be portable to other make implementations, or is it OK to use GNU-specific features? 020_installation.md describes it as a "GNU Makefile", but nothing actually seems to say that GNU make is required.

column21:
Another issue with the cflags branch is that it adds -std=c99. In gcc and glibc, this is interpreted as a request to act as a very strict C99 compiler, disabling many GNU extensions - in particular, readlink() isn't declared, and inline assembly in asm() isn't recognised (although I think __asm__(), which is in the namespace for system-specific extensions, still is).
One way to deal with this would be to use -std=gnu99 (which is C99 with GNU extensions), or to not use a -std option at all (because the default in any vaguely recent gcc version is gnu99 or newer). This is the approach I'd be inclined to use.
Another would be to get the readlink declaration by using feature test macros (Linux readlink(2) says defining _XOPEN_SOURCE to a value >= 500, or _POSIX_C_SOURCE to a value >= 200112L, should work; or you could define _GNU_SOURCE which enables all the extensions), and to use __asm__ for inline assembly. That effectively means you're requesting a very strict C99 environment, and then making targeted exceptions for specific extensions beyond C99.

column21:
One way to deal with this would be to use -std=gnu99 (which is C99 with GNU extensions)

It used to be -std=gnu99 before the cflags branch.
It does seem weird to be telling the compiler in the Makefile "please implement C99", and then ask it in src/common/header/shared.h whether it's implementing C11...
Just removing -std doesn't seem to work with my compiler (gcc 9.2.1): it defaults to C11 mode, but in C11 mode, in src/common/header/shared.h, because __STDC_VERSION__ is defined to 201112L or later, we define YQ2_ATTR_NORETURN as _Noreturn. Unfortunately, gcc doesn't seem to interpret _Noreturn as being valid to attach to function pointers (unlike its __attribute__((__noreturn__)) extension), but there are a couple of function pointers tagged with YQ2_ATTR_NORETURN, causing the build to fail in C11 mode.

column21:
It used to be -std=gnu99 before the cflags branch.

Yeah, that was my fault. I'll force push the change back to gnu99 in a few minutes. On FreeBSD there's no difference in libc between c99 and gnu99, therefor I didn't notice it.

Is the Makefile intended to be portable to other make implementations, or is it OK to use GNU-specific features? 020_installation.md describes it as a "GNU Makefile", but nothing actually seems to say that GNU make is required.

We've never targeted other make implementations besides GNU make and I don't think that the Makefile will work with anything else. I just gave it a try with FreeBSDs bmake (backward compatible to pmake) and there're 265 errors while parsing the Makefile... I've marked all global additions to the CFLAGS and LDFLAGS as override. And added INCLUDE to the list of overideable variables.

It does seem weird to be telling the compiler in the Makefile "please implement C99", and then ask it in src/common/header/shared.h whether it's implementing C11...

Not really. :) We're building in C99 mode, because we want stay compatible with older compilers. And maybe one day we'll port the code MSVC, every feature from newer C standards will make that harder... On the other hand we're adding C11 pathes for everything that isn't covered in older standards, it'll make ports to other C11 compliant compilers with no or only a few GNU extensions easier

column21:
Thank you,

On what GPUs and platforms was this tested? Does it pass validation cleanly?

Code have tested on RADV and SwiftShader with enabled _DEBUG and VK_LAYER_KHRONOS_validation.

Also the spec-required minimum for "maximum memory allocations" can be as low as 4096. Are you sure you're never allocating more images and buffers than that?

Yes, quake has own limitation of amount objects(images/buffers) and it never more than we had on end of 90s.

Is not having to compile one file as C++ worth all that?

We have used very limited subset of vulkan functionality and usage only one language in whole code base is worth it. vk_utils is ported from q2vkpt and q2rtx, if we have issues with code in future, we always can backport solution from nvidia rtx version.

column21:
Hi,
I had a discussion about this with some people that know a lot more than me about ARM. The general consent is:

For 32-Bit ARM it should be okay to force -march=armv6k. It would cover everything starting from the first RPi generation and older cores are too slow for YQ2 anyway.
For 64-Bit ARM we could force -march=armv8.0-a, it would cover all aarch64 compatible cores.

Forcing the architecture to a sane minimum would simplify the code, because you don't need to communicate into the code if the build supports the yield opcode.

column21: Hrm. Apparently it's armv8.0-a on clang and armv8-a on gcc. At least my clang also accepts armv8-a, so let's see if someone complains. If so we'll need to set arch depending on the compiler.

column13: Add a separate noreturn macro for function pointers
column20:
C11 _Noreturn is only accepted on function declarations, not on function
pointers, so we can't use it on callbacks like game_import_t.error and
refimport_t.Sys_Error. Use a separate macro for those.
The problematic situation doesn't currently happen because the Makefile
hard-codes -std=gnu99, which disables C11 features; but removing
-std=gnu99 (resulting in the compiler's default, currently gnu11) causes
compilation failures with at least gcc 9.x.

As discussed briefly on #523, this isn't a practical problem right now, but will become a practical problem if porting to C11 compilers in future.

column13: WIP: arm: Don't use yield if unsupported
column20:
(See below for updated description of branch)
Building with a -march= argument attempts to override the compiler's
configuration. In distributions that target a higher baseline CPU
than we specify, -march=armv6k will force the compiler to try to build
for ARMv6K specifically, rather than that higher baseline.
For example, in Debian's "armhf" port (like many 32-bit ARM ports), the
compiler targets ARMv7 with the VFPv3D16 floating-point extensions, and
the port explicitly does not support older CPUs. Asking it to build for
armv6k just fails, which appears to be because armv6k implies an older
VFP (floating point) ABI than anything this compiler supports. Even if
it succeeded, it would produce binaries that unnecessarily do not take
full advantage of the distribution's ARMv7 baseline.
Conversely, in distributions that target a lower baseline CPU than
we specify, building with an explicit -march= option will produce an
executable that cannot run successfully on the distribution's baseline
CPU. For example, Debian's "armel" port (ARMv5TE) and the baseline used in
Raspbian (ARMv6, with no K) are designed to be compatible with older ARM
CPUs, even if the CPU they are actually run on in practice might be newer,
such as the ARMv7 in the Raspberry Pi version 2. Individual packages in
these distributions are not generally allowed to override that baseline.
Instead, let the distribution or user set their target CPU (distributions
configure their gcc to default to a specified baseline, while users can
put -march=native or another suitable -march= option in their CFLAGS if
they want a binary suitable for their specific system), and conditionally
enable the yield instruction at compile-time if that target CPU has
it. As far as I can find out, yield was added in ARMv6K, a minor revision
of ARMv6, so it should be available in all ARMv7 or higher CPUs (which
includes anything 64-bit), plus ARMv6 CPUs if they are actually ARMv6K.
Using -march=armv8-a on 64-bit ARM (aarch64) was unnecessary in any
case, because it is the oldest form of aarch64: the only effect of that
option would be to disable newer functionality if the compiler defaults
to enabling it (which I suspect no distributions do yet, but they might
consider in a few years' time).

I believe this is correct, but it might be too conservative: adding || defined(__ARM_ARCH_6KZ__) to the condition might also work (I'm unsure whether ARMv6KZ is strictly a superset of ARMv6K).
This has been successfully compiled (although not tested at runtime) on Debian armhf and armel, with some #warning to tell me which code path it's taking. It appears to enable the yield instruction on armhf (ARMv7) but not on armel (ARMv5), which is what should happen here.
cc @devnexen, @0lvin

column21: The Raspbian compiler is configured to default to ARMv6 so that the binaries it produces will run on any Raspberry Pi (including version 1, which was ARMv6). I'd recommend using -march=armv7 or -march=native if you have something newer and you don't need your binaries to be portable to older RPi models.

column21: Yes, I suppose it is. Picking a specific CPU to target isn't really yquake2's job: it helps some distributions and users, but hurts others. The compiler vendor (in your case Raspbian) and the user who is compiling binaries (you) are both better-placed to choose a baseline than the maintainer of an arbitrary piece of software that is being compiled.

column21:
So you want builds for 32-bit ARM to default to requiring ARMv6K or up if a user doesn't specify otherwise? That's doable, although I think ARMv7 would probably be a better default. Most 32-bit ARM distros have ARMv7 as their baseline (that's why Debian chose ARMv7 for armhf), with Raspbian being the notable exception.
I don't think the Raspberry Pi v1 is ARMv6K, just ARMv6, so the practical result for Raspberry Pi users (works on version 2 and up, doesn't work on version 1) would be the same with -march=armv7 baseline as with -march=armv6k (although maybe with a bit better code generated).
On Debian armhf and similar distributions, -march=armv6k doesn't compile, whereas -march=armv7 would.

column21:
How about this? (Work in progress.)



arm: Only use yield instruction if supported
The default on 32-bit ARM is now -march=armv6k, but it's overridable,
and must be overridden on some toolchains that have a higher baseline
and cannot compile for -march=armv6k. This includes Debian armhf
(ARMv7 with the VFPv3D16 floating-point extensions), where armv6k
appears to imply an older VFP (floating point) ABI than anything the
compiler supports.
Conditionally enable the yield instruction at compile-time if the target
CPU has it. As far as I can find out, yield was added in ARMv6K, a minor
revision of ARMv6, so it should be available in all ARMv7 or higher CPUs
(which includes anything 64-bit), plus ARMv6 CPUs if they are actually
ARMv6K.


Don't force target CPU to armv8-a on aarch64
ARMv8-A is the oldest/most-limited/least-extended version of aarch64,
analogous to the earliest AMD 64-bit processor in the x86 world.
As a result, forcing this target CPU can only disable features, and
isn't going to enable anything we might want. The yield opcode was
added in ARMv7, and all aarch64 CPUs are ARMv8-A or higher (which is
a superset of ARMv7), so no special architecture specification is
necessary to access the yield opcode.



I've marked this as WIP because of the following issues:


The first commit message says it's overridable, but having that actually work requires merging the cflags branch first.


As noted above, if you want the default on 32-bit ARM to be representative of CPUs people actually have, I suspect better options are either trust the compiler vendor to have done the right thing (as in the original version of this branch), or go for ARMv7 (which will work on Raspberry Pi v2 or later but not on the Raspberry Pi v1 or Raspberry Pi Zero, the same as Debian armhf and Fedora ARMv7).

column13: WIP: arm: Don't use yield if unsupported
column20:
(See below for updated description of branch)
Building with a -march= argument attempts to override the compiler's
configuration. In distributions that target a higher baseline CPU
than we specify, -march=armv6k will force the compiler to try to build
for ARMv6K specifically, rather than that higher baseline.
For example, in Debian's "armhf" port (like many 32-bit ARM ports), the
compiler targets ARMv7 with the VFPv3D16 floating-point extensions, and
the port explicitly does not support older CPUs. Asking it to build for
armv6k just fails, which appears to be because armv6k implies an older
VFP (floating point) ABI than anything this compiler supports. Even if
it succeeded, it would produce binaries that unnecessarily do not take
full advantage of the distribution's ARMv7 baseline.
Conversely, in distributions that target a lower baseline CPU than
we specify, building with an explicit -march= option will produce an
executable that cannot run successfully on the distribution's baseline
CPU. For example, Debian's "armel" port (ARMv5TE) and the baseline used in
Raspbian (ARMv6, with no K) are designed to be compatible with older ARM
CPUs, even if the CPU they are actually run on in practice might be newer,
such as the ARMv7 in the Raspberry Pi version 2. Individual packages in
these distributions are not generally allowed to override that baseline.
Instead, let the distribution or user set their target CPU (distributions
configure their gcc to default to a specified baseline, while users can
put -march=native or another suitable -march= option in their CFLAGS if
they want a binary suitable for their specific system), and conditionally
enable the yield instruction at compile-time if that target CPU has
it. As far as I can find out, yield was added in ARMv6K, a minor revision
of ARMv6, so it should be available in all ARMv7 or higher CPUs (which
includes anything 64-bit), plus ARMv6 CPUs if they are actually ARMv6K.
Using -march=armv8-a on 64-bit ARM (aarch64) was unnecessary in any
case, because it is the oldest form of aarch64: the only effect of that
option would be to disable newer functionality if the compiler defaults
to enabling it (which I suspect no distributions do yet, but they might
consider in a few years' time).

I believe this is correct, but it might be too conservative: adding || defined(__ARM_ARCH_6KZ__) to the condition might also work (I'm unsure whether ARMv6KZ is strictly a superset of ARMv6K).
This has been successfully compiled (although not tested at runtime) on Debian armhf and armel, with some #warning to tell me which code path it's taking. It appears to enable the yield instruction on armhf (ARMv7) but not on armel (ARMv5), which is what should happen here.
cc @devnexen, @0lvin
column21:
I've just merged the cflags branch. Now there's a conflict in the Makefile, because I moved the -march= stuff further up and added a longer comment explaining the rationale behind it and what to do if someone really wants to build for ARM5 or older ARM6 CPUs. Can you resolve it? After that i'll merge this PR and hopefully everybody is happy. :)
Regarding the minimum architecture: Everything up to and including the RPi 3B+ is too slow for playing Quake II. That's mostly caused by the crappy GPU driver and it's dead slow legacy OpenGL implementation. I'm getting about 37 FPS at 640x480... For more performance we would need an OpenGL ES 2.0 renderer. I don't think that we'll ever write one, it's too much work for an already  outdated niche platform. The RPi 4 has an OpenGL ES 3.0 compatible GPU, adding an ES 3.0 path to the GL3 renderer is rather easy. We had an experiment implementation somewhere during the GL3 development, it was abandoned due to the lack of hardware. We'll likely revive it some day.
So going to ARMv7 as the default minimum shouldn't be a big problem. We could just go for -march=armv7 and see if anyone complains.

column13: Fix for some items playing wrong sound when instantly used
column20:
Fix for bug #547.
I defined a new item flag, IT_INSTANT_USE, that tags items that will be instantly used when picked up in instant-use deathmatch games (deathmatch 1 and dmflags & 16), and I moved the instant use code out of Pickup_Powerup/Pickup_Sphere and into Touch_Item so that the use action overrides the generic pickup sound event, making sure original sound prioritization is maintained.
In my testing I did not discover any unwanted side-effects and the bug is fixed, but I definitely invite others to try this out if they can.
column21:
Fix for bug #547.
I defined a new item flag, IT_INSTANT_USE, that tags items that will be instantly used when picked up in instant-use deathmatch games (deathmatch 1 and dmflags & 16), and I moved the instant use code out of Pickup_Powerup/Pickup_Sphere and into Touch_Item so that the use action overrides the generic pickup sound event, making sure original sound prioritization is maintained.
In my testing I did not discover any unwanted side-effects and the bug is fixed, but I definitely invite others to try this out if they can.

column13: Implement accurate-aiming CVAR in baseq2 game code.
column20:
Awhile ago, I raised issue #379 about whether there was anything that could be done to improve the aiming in-game.
Essentially, I've taken this implementation from Berserker@QuakeII v1.41 that provides the accurate aiming I've desired for so long and placed it behind a CVAR so that it's not enabled by default.
I hope with this change being optional, it can be considered for merging into the port. There are many forum posts online about Quake II and how to get accurate aiming, so I believe this would be desirable by many players.

column13: Don't play silenced muzzle flash sounds
column20:
Experimental approach to fix play sound queue.
The idea is to skip playing muzzle flash sound if it's audio data is empty or contains only silence (or very close to it).
See #558 for details.

column21:
Added cvar s_ps_sorting to control sorting of play sounds.
Values:
1 (default) New sorting for mission packs only (including Quake 2 itself) or the old one otherwise.
2 New sorting.
3 New sorting and skip muzzle flash sounds if they are silence.

column21: I gave it a try with Address Sanitizer enabled. As far I can tell from about 20 runs with AMD, Intel and Nvidia GPUs we don't have a memory corruption somewhere in our code; at least Address Sanitizer doesn't trigger. Interestingly I can reproduce the crash to nearly 100% on my desktop with an about 6 weeks old Arch Linux and an Radeon 5770 XT but I have never seen it on my Laptop with an Intel GPU. I'll update the desktop sometime next week and see if it's still a problem with newer packages. There're at least some crash fixes in Mesa / RADV that I don't have.

column13: Fixed the Jorg skin bug present since the original Quake 2 release.
column20:
I fixed this in my own project and figured it might be worth to move it to Yamagi Quake 2, since it seems to still have that bug present.
Jorg and Makron models need to be swapped in order for the "hurt" skin to trigger correctly - right now, if Jorg has < 50% of health, it's the Makron's skin that's being replaced instead of the Jorg's. This fix has been tested in vkQuake2 but I see that multi-model entities (I think Jorg is the only one) are handled in the same manner here.

column13: Enable rpath with Mac OS linker
column20:
It looks like when you made RPATH optional here: b48cc47, the build will try to call the linker with arguments that Mac OS's linker doesn't like. Here is a working fix, I've only tested on Mac OS 10.15.4 though.
I've also added WITH_RPATH to the config info that gets printed when building.
Here's some info about Mac OS's linker, but I'm certainly no expert in it either: https://jorgen.tjer.no/post/2014/05/20/dt-rpath-ld-and-at-rpath-dyld/
Edit: I should include the original failure here as well. This is what happens on master right now when building on Mac OS:
===> LD release/quake2
ld: unknown option: -z
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make[1]: *** [release/quake2] Error 1
make: *** [client] Error 2

column20: Added command 'listmaps' to list available maps to load through the console. It will list maps in pak files first followed by maps in the 'maps/' folder from baseq2 or mod or expansion being played.
column21:
I'm not sure how we should sort this. At the moment, the the maps that
come from paks will listed in their order of appearence in their pak.
Files that are stored in the maps/ folder will be appear in a
alphabetically sorted manner.

In the screenshot provided with my pull request. Maps listed from
'mine1' to 'boss2' are maps from the baseq2 pak files. 'angron1a' and
'angron1b' are custom maps which are present in the 'maps/' subdirectory
in baseq2.

I feel this is fine because users of this command will probably be
interested in listing the map names from their maps/ folder to know
which custom map to load. If there's a better idea on the overall
sorting though, I'd be glad to give it a go on the implementation side.

column13: Start Server Menu: reload "maps.lst" after "game" dir is changed
column20: The data read from "maps.lst" is only ever read once currently, but this change implemented in "FS_BuildGameSpecificSearchPath" causes it to be read again if the "game" cvar/directory is updated.  NOTE: I made this change on an older branch (I'm no longer able to compile locally from about 7.40 onward) but it looks like it shouldn't be impacted by intervening updates.

column13: Create "mods" submenu to allow changing "game" cvar via UI
column20:
Combs all Raw search paths to find game dirs containing PAK/PK2/PK3
files (similar to Q3's mod recognition method).  If multiple uniquely-named directories exist, then show a "mods"
option on the "Game" menu and allow selection of desired mod on new
eponymous submenu.  Compiles & play-tests on Linux Mint including the latest yquake2/yquake2 changes as of Sept 1.

Hi,
that's a nice idea. And good work! The code looks clean and easy understandable But, I hate to say this: Welcome to the wonderful world of the Quake II virtual file system. ;) The file system is buggy, most bugs cannot be fixed (because mods may rely on them) and them and we fiddled things like more dynamic search paths into it while staying bug to bug compatible... column21:
Using Address Sanitizer was easier than I expected.  I've pushed an update to my fork so opening this PR back up, expecting it will pick it up.  In addition to correcting my memory leaks, I've also added verification that any params the mod-finder passes to "FS_ListFiles" are formatted properly and any NULL data it returns gets ignored, so mods in "datadir" are located correctly.
I'll use a separate branch in my fork next time.

column20:
When using the command to load a map "map x", if one character from the map name is provided, it will try to autocomplete it.
There are 3 possible scenarios I anticipated:

The name is an exact match. In this case we do nothing.
The name is partially filled out and only 1 match was found. In this case we fill out the rest.
The name has many matches. In this case we complete the map name with the characters from the matches until one differs. We also provide the list of the current matches.

Add vstr command and nextdemo variable for support ioquake3 style benchmark commands like:
unbindall

timedemo 1
set nextdemo quit
set demoloop "demomap q2demo1.dm2"
vstr demoloop

With run by
./quake2 +exec pts.cfg +set r_mode 5 +set r_fullscreen 0 +set com_speeds 1
based on Phoronix Test Suite::OpenArena

column13: Cast arguments to ctype functions to unsigned char
column20: According to the C standard, arguments to the ctype functions must fit into unsigned char (presumably so they can be implemented with simple array access). This causes a build time warning on NetBSD, and may function incorrectly if any UTF-8 strings are used.
column21: According to the C standard, arguments to the ctype functions must fit into unsigned char (presumably so they can be implemented with simple array access). This causes a build time warning on NetBSD, and may function incorrectly if any UTF-8 strings are used.

column13: Cast arguments to ctype functions to unsigned char
column20: According to the C standard, arguments to the ctype functions must fit into unsigned char (presumably so they can be implemented with simple array access). This causes a build time warning on NetBSD, and may function incorrectly if any UTF-8 strings are used.
column21:
Those functions don't work correctly with UTF-8 either way - for that they'd have to be able to handle multiple chars at once.
But I think they're only used with ASCII anyway

column13: Cast arguments to ctype functions to unsigned char
column20: According to the C standard, arguments to the ctype functions must fit into unsigned char (presumably so they can be implemented with simple array access). This causes a build time warning on NetBSD, and may function incorrectly if any UTF-8 strings are used.
column21: The behaviour for codepoints outside of ASCII range (i.e. utf-8 values packed into unsigned char) is to ignore them. However, the behaviour for codepoints below 0 (i.e. utf-8 values packed into signed char) is undefined nasal demons.

column21: The function pointers are used by the savegame system. When saving the game, all function pointers in all structs holding the games state are placed with strings. When loading the game, the strings are turned into functions pointers again. This way the game can be altered (recompiled with another compiler version, bug fixes and even new features integrated,  etc.) without breaking savegame compatibility. While P_ProjectSource() isn't referenced through function pointers and therefor not used by the savegame system, correcting the prototype is correct way to go.

column13: Add UI to configure joystick sensitivity, support joystick expo
column20:
Changes

Add support for joy_expo cvar with default value of 2 that makes joystick input non-linear. This enables both precise and fast movements, even at higher sensitivity levels.
Adds a "customize joystick" sub-menu that provides sliders for changing the sensitivity and expo applied to joystick inputs.
Allows setting mouse sensitivity to 0 in UI to work around a RetroPie bug where controller input was showing up as both joystick and mouse events

More on expo
This article does a good job of explaining how this works.

Left: a linear yaw response. Right: an exponential yaw response.
Effectively, with this change, small movements make for fine aiming, big movements make for fast movement.
Notes
Tested on RetroPie and it works great, the game is much more playable and I'm able to aim more accurately. I found I like the following settings:
set joy_expo "3.700000"
set joy_forwardsensitivity "1"
set joy_pitchsensitivity "0.550000"
set joy_sidesensitivity "1"
set joy_yawsensitivity "0.750000"

Additionally, adjusting the deadzones makes things much more accurate:
set joy_axis_leftx_threshold "0.025"
set joy_axis_lefty_threshold "0.025"
set joy_axis_rightx_threshold "0.025"
set joy_axis_righty_threshold "0.025"

@Yamagi thanks for the insight! Adding IN_JoyAltSelectorUp() to In_FlushQueue() and calling In_FlushQueue() from CL_ParseServerData() and did the trick.
I did not opt to call IN_JoyAltSelectorUpI() inside of Key_MarkAllUp() as cl_keyboard.c is not currently including input.h, and it seemed out of place to deal with joystick matters in cl_keyboard.c. Let me know if you feel otherwise and I will make the change.

column13: Add resolution scaling to Vulkan renderer
column20:
This commit adds a new cvar called vk_pixel_size that represents how big
pixels should look in the rendered world in order to simulate lower
screen resolutions. With its default value of 1 everything looks normal,
but with bigger sizes (e.g. 4) the rendered world starts to look
"pixelated" due to pixels appearing bigger.
To implement the effect, the viewport and scissor are modified when
drawing the world so the rendering results cover a smaller area in the
top-left corner of the image.
The post-processing fragment shader is used to scale the image back to
the swapchain size before drawing UI elements on top of it.
The UI is not affected by this change, so the existing UI scaling
options continue to work as before with no changes, adding some
flexibility to the mix.
Related to feature request #588.

It's similar, just less noticeable depending on the resolution, screen size, etc. vk_pixel_size determines the length of the square side in pixels. Value 1 means pixels are 1x1 squares (as usual), value 2 means they are 2x2, 3 means 3x3, 4 means 4x4, etc.
The following screenshots were taken with sizes 1, 2 and 4.

column13: Add resolution scaling to Vulkan renderer
column20:
This commit adds a new cvar called vk_pixel_size that represents how big
pixels should look in the rendered world in order to simulate lower
screen resolutions. With its default value of 1 everything looks normal,
but with bigger sizes (e.g. 4) the rendered world starts to look
"pixelated" due to pixels appearing bigger.
To implement the effect, the viewport and scissor are modified when
drawing the world so the rendering results cover a smaller area in the
top-left corner of the image.
The post-processing fragment shader is used to scale the image back to
the swapchain size before drawing UI elements on top of it.
The UI is not affected by this change, so the existing UI scaling
options continue to work as before with no changes, adding some
flexibility to the mix.
Related to feature request #588.
column21:
The world is still rendered in the chosen screen resolution and the game performs accordingly.

Wouldn't it make more sense to render at the appropriate lower resolution (e.g. 0.5*w, 0.5*h for vk_pixel_size 2) and scale that up to the real resolution in the postprocess step?
Should look the same, but have the advantage of additionally making rendering cheaper (maybe especially interesting once Vulkan support on Raspberry Pi is available in Raspbian)
(Might be more work though)

column21: Indeed, it probably made more sense but I thought it would be much more complicated. However, I gave it a shot today and it turns out we can simply scale back the viewport and scissor when rendering the world and it works. I've updated the branch and the top comment.

column13: Makefile: Fix architecture detection on Windows
column20:
$PROCESSOR_ARCHITECTURE seems to contain the architecture of the host,
but we need the architecture the current MinGW shell is targeting.
$MINGW_CHOST seems to be just that, and on my system it's either
i686-w64-mingw32 (mingw32.exe) or x86_64-w64-mingw32 (mingw64.exe)
(No idea what it looks like for Windows on ARM...)
Now this is correctly set and also SSE is used for floating point math which fixes weird lightmap bugs we've been seeing.

column20:
A couple of skybox-related fixes for Vulkan.

Fix skybox edges being visible due to texture coordinates by using CLAMP_TO_EDGE addressing in samplers when drawing it
Fix black pixels along skybox edges due to skyboxes not being watertight.

Fixes #639.

column21: Thank you for looking into this and coding the fix. I wonder why we never saw this in GL3. As far as I remeber we had a lot of problems with (unfixable) inconsistencies in the precalculated visibility sets of world geometry, but never with the skyboxes. Anyways: Merged!

column21: Glad I could help! I barely know OpenGL, but when I looked at how a frame is drawn in OpenGL from Renderdoc, it looked like it was using the same trick I pulled off in Vulkan: the contents of the previous frame are still in the color buffer while the new frame is being drawn, so it could mask the error.

column21: So the only real change is to allow the upload of samples with 2 channels into OpenAL and SDL. That apparently works for samples that are played on the players position, because they aren't spartialized. But what happens if stereo samples are spartialized? I think that nothing would happen with OpenAL, because the library is usually safe against such things. But what about SDL? Not that I'm against the change, I just try to understand what possible could go wrong.

make internal functions static.
column21:
So the only real change is to allow the upload of samples with 2 channels into OpenAL and SDL.

Yes, changes contain only remove mono/stereo check. All other changes are related only to the code style or remove unused code.
About SDL/OpenAl behaiviour:

SDL audio works without any issues or changes from our side for mod. Maybe it has some issues that I have not caught.
OpenAL has differences in sound behavior, when defender soldier took attention - sound is too loud and long if compare to original sound.

I have resolved OpenAl by replace to stereo files based on origin:
ffmpeg -i SOLSGHT1.wav -af "pan=stereo|c0=c0|c1=c0" sound/soldier/solsght1.wav
ffmpeg -i SOLSGHT1.wav -af "pan=stereo|c0=c0|c1=c0" sound/soldier/solsrch1.wav
SOLSGHT1.wav: RIFF (little-endian) data, WAVE audio, Microsoft PCM, 16 bit, mono 22050 Hz
sound/soldier/solsght1.wav: RIFF (little-endian) data, WAVE audio, Microsoft PCM, 16 bit, stereo 22050 Hz

As i expect that it related to sound volume <-> distance function to source.
If we speak about regressions with original mono sound - code works without any issues as I see. And we can advertise this functionality as initial implementation that required changes in mods or at least checking ;-)

make internal functions static.

column20:
This branch fixes a number of problems present in Vulkan when in fullscreen mode, and other related problems.

First off and most importantly, it fixes #648, making fullscreen images look correctly and have the right aspect ratio when vid_fullscreen is 1.
Second, it restores textured borders around the world view when scaling the view down.
Finally, it center the game "window" in the screen with vid_fullscreen 1, which should be more comfortable.

Edit: edited to reflect branch updates.

column20:
A few more Vulkan fixes for things I noticed this week.


Textured borders for scaled down views were not working properly with MSAA enabled, due to the texture quad pipeline being prepared only for single-sample attachments (it's mainly used for drawing UI elements in the UI render pass, which is always single-sampled). Could this have been the original reason for the black borders hack?


Framebuffer contents from the previous frame (used to mask geometry glitches) were not being correctly loaded with MSAA enabled. Geometry glitches, as seen in the skybox, are not as noticeable with MSAA enabled so I didn't notice this until I analyzed a frame with renderdoc. This is a mistake I introduced earlier and its solution also increases framerate with MSAA enabled. 🤷 In my GTX 1070 I jump from 375 fps to ~440 fps in 1600x1200 with MSAA 8x.


Given the Vulkan backend uses 3 render passes with a single subpass each, specifying barriers using subpass dependencies felt weird to me, so I've replaced them with proper memory barriers between render passes. I believe they're easier to understand and reason about.

column21: I think Vulkan recommended behavior is to use subpass dependencies instead of explicit memory barriers, the driver might be able to schedule them better. Also using global memory barries like you're doing (instead of image or buffer barriers) is a rather heavy hammer and might cost some performance on some devices.

column21:
I'll look into it, no problem. I think @turol has a point and I need to review the spec in detail. External subpass dependencies are used in Vulkan to put memory barriers controlling layout transitions when the initial image layout doesn't match the layout used in the subpass, and when the layout during the subpass does not match the final image layout. This does happen here, so we probably need them in some form. In addition, we may have to keep some of the extra barriers I'm adding in this PR.
I know I promised to take a look at some of this stuff last week, including crashes reported in another issues, but I've been a bit busy due to pandemic-related matters. I'll take a look ASAP.

column20:
A few more Vulkan fixes for things I noticed this week.


Textured borders for scaled down views were not working properly with MSAA enabled, due to the texture quad pipeline being prepared only for single-sample attachments (it's mainly used for drawing UI elements in the UI render pass, which is always single-sampled). Could this have been the original reason for the black borders hack?


Framebuffer contents from the previous frame (used to mask geometry glitches) were not being correctly loaded with MSAA enabled. Geometry glitches, as seen in the skybox, are not as noticeable with MSAA enabled so I didn't notice this until I analyzed a frame with renderdoc. This is a mistake I introduced earlier and its solution also increases framerate with MSAA enabled. 🤷 In my GTX 1070 I jump from 375 fps to ~440 fps in 1600x1200 with MSAA 8x.


Given the Vulkan backend uses 3 render passes with a single subpass each, specifying barriers using subpass dependencies felt weird to me, so I've replaced them with proper memory barriers between render passes. I believe they're easier to understand and reason about.
column21:
So I've changed the branch a bit restoring and tuning the previous external subpass dependencies and keeping the convenient Qvk_MemoryBarrier function. I've studied the spec in more detail and I could even write a blog post explaining my reasoning for the changes, because Vulkan synchronization is not easy to explain in a few words. The summary would be:
First, as I mentioned above, external subpass dependencies are used to control layout transitions from the initial layout of the attachment in the render pass to the layout in the first subpass that uses the attachment, and from the last layout to the final layout specified in the render pass. In our case, these layout transitions happen and must be controlled so images are not transitioned before all operations have completed on them, creating a race. Most of my initial changes have been reverted because the memory barriers I introduced, while correct from the point of view of stages and data dependencies, do not allow us to control these layout transitions.
Second, the first external subpass dependency has been modified. After the skybox fixes we now want to load the color buffer contents from the previous frame before drawing on it again, and this was not correctly taken into account. For the first subpass dependency (used from previous render passes to rendering the world), we need to transition the color attachment before color attachment read operations (i.e. the attachment load) are performed, so I've added that access to the dependency.
Third an finally, a remark on global memory barriers and the question of them being a heavy hammer: I've seen several people, most notably Axel Gneiting from id Software who worked on the renderers for the new Doom games, mention in the Khronos Slack that they use memory barriers for synchronization as the general mechanism, and only fall back to image memory barriers when they want to also perform an image layout transition. While a global memory barrier does look like a heavy hammer, they're much easier to use and apparently it's standard industry practice, so I wouldn't worry too much about it if you want to use them somewhere else.
Sorry for the wall of text. Hope this clears things up. 😄
PS: Please do not merge yet. I'll add more changes to fix #659.

column21:
@rg3 After merge looks like we have new warning message with vk_validation=2, could you please check?
VK_WARNING: Validation Performance Warning: [ UNASSIGNED-BestPractices-vkCreateRenderPass-image-requires-memory ] Object 0: handle = 0x62800001c100, type = VK_OBJECT_TYPE_DEVICE; | MessageID = 0x4003982 | Attachment 2 in the VkRenderPass is a multisampled image with 4 samples, but it uses loadOp/storeOp which requires accessing data from memory. Multisampled images should always be loadOp = CLEAR or DONT_CARE, storeOp = DONT_CARE. This allows the implementation to use lazily allocated memory effectively. (performance)

column20:
Specify correct protection flags when calling mmap() on FreeBSD.
prot | PROT_MAX (prot) are the correct flags because just PROT_MAX
(prot) leaves current protection flags set to PROT_NONE which causes
segmentation fault when reading or writing to the mapped region.

column13: Avoid restarting the whole video on VK_ERROR_OUT_OF_DATE_KHR
column20:
While attempting to solve #659 I started the game in fullscreen mode under Gnome and immediately discovered the game entered an infinite renderer restart loop. A few seconds after the renderer had been initialized and was already drawing frames, it received VK_ERROR_OUT_OF_DATE_KHR, which triggered a restart of the whole video system. The game flickered while restarting it (including creating a new game window, I guess) and the story repeated itself a few seconds later.
It appears this is a known issue and also affects or affected vkQuake and vkQuake2 and @kondrak solved some months ago by restarting Vulkan without touching the game Window. This pull request implements a similar solution, simplified (so probably incomplete 😛) and adapted to yquake2.
This PR can be considered work-in-progress and testing is welcome. At least it solves the infinite reload problem for me. Hopefully, but unlikely, it also solves #659. While doing some back-and-forth switching from "keep resolution" to "switch resolution" and vice versa, I also made the running demo "crash" to the game console with:
********************
ERROR: Mod_PointInLeaf: bad model
********************

And in those situations I also get the following validation error:
==== ShutdownGame ====
VUID-VkPresentInfoKHR-pImageIndices-01296(ERROR / SPEC): msgNum: -945112042 - Validation Error: [ VUID-VkPresentInfoKHR-pImageIndices-01296 ] Object 0: handle = 0x3b83d28, type = VK_OBJECT_TYPE_QUEUE; | MessageID = 0xc7aabc16 | vkQueuePresentKHR(): Images passed to present must be in layout VK_IMAGE_LAYOUT_PRESENT_SRC_KHR or VK_IMAGE_LAYOUT_SHARED_PRESENT_KHR but is in VK_IMAGE_LAYOUT_UNDEFINED. The Vulkan spec states: Each element of pImageIndices must be the index of a presentable image acquired from the swapchain specified by the corresponding element of the pSwapchains array, and the presented image subresource must be in the VK_IMAGE_LAYOUT_PRESENT_SRC_KHR layout at the time the operation is executed on a VkDevice (https://github.com/KhronosGroup/Vulkan-Docs/search?q=)VUID-VkPresentInfoKHR-pImageIndices-01296)
    Objects: 1
        [0] 0x3b83d28, type: 4, name: NULL

So my guess is there's still work to do.

column21:
I gave it some more testing. I'm pretty sure that the crash is fixed. So I'm merging this.

I'll probably try to find the cause for the Mod_PointInLeaf error in the near future.

Now that I know that the problem exist and how I can trigger it, it's easy to reproduce. I've never seen that error before, though.

I also want to play the full game with the Vulkan renderer to see if I detect some other issues.

I recently did a full run of baseq2, xatrix and rogue on commit 6f045f7. I didn't observe any render glitches, at least nothing obvious.

@Yamagi @rg3 @DanielGibson Could please you look? Should we remove this hacks, what do you think?
Look as it is not required after set r_mode to -2 for fullscreen. Maybe we could have different way of 'keep resolution' for each render? Like gl based renders will use full desktop resolution, soft will scale selected resolution to correct aspect ratio and vulkan will use centered/desktop resolution with custom vk_pixel_size.

I think we should keep them. While the menu forces r_mode -2 when selecting 'fullscreen window' the user can still set vid_fullscreen 2 with any r_mode through the console. And there's the corner case that the game might be unable to determine the desktop resolution.
Anyways, thank you for fixing my oversights.

column20:
This pull request essentially fixes two issues:


ERROR: Mod_PointInLeaf: bad model when restarting the Vulkan renderer. This is solved by making the restart happen at the end of the frame instead of at the beginning of it, and signaling the server the client needs to be re-registered again to rebuild the list of models.


Memory leak when restarting the Vulkan renderer, due to "models_known" not being freed before allocating it again.


For the first point I used the same approach taken in vkQuake2 of using a global cvar_t called vid_refresh. It's my understanding, from reading other parts of the code, that such an approach is a bit hackish and there should be a message sent from the client  to the server to properly communicate this, but my knowledge of the code base is lacking here, so I preferred to get the fix out and let others with more experience tune it as needed.
column21:
This pull request essentially fixes two issues:


ERROR: Mod_PointInLeaf: bad model when restarting the Vulkan renderer. This is solved by making the restart happen at the end of the frame instead of at the beginning of it, and signaling the server the client needs to be re-registered again to rebuild the list of models.


Memory leak when restarting the Vulkan renderer, due to "models_known" not being freed before allocating it again.


For the first point I used the same approach taken in vkQuake2 of using a global cvar_t called vid_refresh. It's my understanding, from reading other parts of the code, that such an approach is a bit hackish and there should be a message sent from the client  to the server to properly communicate this, but my knowledge of the code base is lacking here, so I preferred to get the fix out and let others with more experience tune it as needed.

column20:
This pull request essentially fixes two issues:


ERROR: Mod_PointInLeaf: bad model when restarting the Vulkan renderer. This is solved by making the restart happen at the end of the frame instead of at the beginning of it, and signaling the server the client needs to be re-registered again to rebuild the list of models.


Memory leak when restarting the Vulkan renderer, due to "models_known" not being freed before allocating it again.


For the first point I used the same approach taken in vkQuake2 of using a global cvar_t called vid_refresh. Abusing a scvar is a little bit hacky, but the vanilla client does it the same way. The alternative would be to fiddle another shared function pointer into the renderer API. That would break external renderers.

column20:
My original goal with these changes was just fixing #662, but I've fixed a couple of additional issues.
First, I've tweaked the code so changing the anisotropic filter value from the video menu does not apply the change immediately. Instead, now you must hit "Apply" and let the renderer restart. The problem this tries to solve is that, in Vulkan, the anisotropic and texture filter modes are part of the texture sampler object. If you want to support any combination of these parameters independently, you only have two options:


You create a huge number of texture samplers with every combination of texture and anisotropic filter values, and select the one to apply on the fly based on user settings. This is what's used now, but to cut down on the number of combinations the anisotropic filter value in Vulkan is now an on/off switch, and the maximum anisotropy is applied if not off. I wanted to change that.


The second approach is to carefully rebuild texture samplers on the fly when the user requests a change in texture sampling parameters, but this has to be done very carefully. In theory, you must not delete a texture sampler that's already recorded in a command buffer before the command buffer finishes executing and is destroyed. This is not too hard, but the current state of the code doesn't make this easy.


Because video options are changed seldomly, I don't think it's a problem to restart the renderer when the anisotropic filter value is changed. When the renderer starts, texture samplers are created with the appropriate anisotropy value chosen by the user, so it's not longer an on/off switch and we also cut the number of texture samplers almost in half.

column20:
My original goal with these changes was just fixing #662, but I've fixed a couple of additional issues.
First, I've tweaked the code so changing the anisotropic filter value from the video menu does not apply the change immediately. Instead, now you must hit "Apply" and let the renderer restart. The problem this tries to solve is that, in Vulkan, the anisotropic and texture filter modes are part of the texture sampler object. If you want to support any combination of these parameters independently, you only have two options:


You create a huge number of texture samplers with every combination of texture and anisotropic filter values, and select the one to apply on the fly based on user settings. This is what's used now, but to cut down on the number of combinations the anisotropic filter value in Vulkan is now an on/off switch, and the maximum anisotropy is applied if not off. I wanted to change that.


The second approach is to carefully rebuild texture samplers on the fly when the user requests a change in texture sampling parameters, but this has to be done very carefully. In theory, you must not delete a texture sampler that's already recorded in a command buffer before the command buffer finishes executing and is destroyed. This is not too hard, but the current state of the code doesn't make this easy.


Because video options are changed seldomly, I don't think it's a problem to restart the renderer when the anisotropic filter value is changed. When the renderer starts, texture samplers are created with the appropriate anisotropy value chosen by the user, so it's not longer an on/off switch and we also cut the number of texture samplers almost in half.

column21:
Hi,
I hadn't the time to reply to the e-mails. So let's continue here: I can't set self->die in the default case, because it would change the behavior of the commander_body entity. That has a high probability to break existing maps. The commander_body is designed to be indestructible.  If you want it to be destructable and need a self->die pointer, you must set g_commanderbody_nogod to 1. That removes the hardcoded godmode flag and connects the function. You can set the cvar to 1 by default in your mod or merge the code without the cvar guarding it.

I guess that s too much to refactor in one repo like most of doom projects do.

And the licenses are incompatible. Quake II itself is under GPL2, the addons and most 3rd party mods are under the crappy SDK license. Some projects have merged baseq2, ctf, rogue and xarix into one. We won't do it, because it violates the SDL license and id Software, ZeniMax, Microsoft, whoever may not like that.

column13: Map fixes for old and newly discovered bugs + removed code hacks
column20:
This PR fixes the following bugs: #689 #687
In addition I implemented the code hacks as map fixes (city2, city3, cool1, lab), as well as fixing some additional bugs reported within the bug reports (city1). There are other more minor fixes, like fixing "duration is not a field" console warning in biggun and using an orphaned target_explosion entity in base2.
I removed the code hacks for the following reasons:

They make correct configuration more complicated and easy to mess up.
They are incomplete. A lot of the bugs found were not addressed by them and the hack for map "lab" was not even fully working.
Only the absolutely most die-hard Q2 fans will notice any difference, and even then I doubt they will mind having to kill an extra enemy or two in a couple of levels.

I have a question for @Yamagi, how would you like me to document the map fixes in the YQ2 docs?

column21: I don't think that the buttons should be hardcoded. The obvious problem is, that you can never be sure were these buttons are located on the connected controller or if they're available at all. Our controller support is rather rudimentary, mostly due to Quake II not really suited for controller input. The minimum requirement would be something like the 'backbutton hack': https://github.com/yquake2/yquake2/blob/master/src/client/input/sdl.c#L1438 Of course it would be even better to switch to bindings through SDL_GameControllerGetBindForButton() everywhere...

column13: Shark bbox fix and added check for inuse after entity thinking
column20:
This PR fixes bug #704
flipper_dead() sets the dead bbox top and bottom planes incorrectly. This is likely a copy/paste error by id. Unlike most monsters, the flipper's point of origin is at the bottom of its model, so mins[2] is 0, however the death code sets mins to -24 and maxs to -8, not only moving the bbox but actually leaving the model completely.
This makes it hard for the player to know where to actually shoot to gib the dead body, and because the bbox moves, it means it might clip into the world and this causes the entity to freefall forever.
I fixed this by keeping maxs[2] unchanged and doing a trace downwards by 8 units, so mins[2] will be anywhere from 0 to -8 based on if/when the trace hits an obstacle.
I also snuck in a small inuse check after SV_RunThink() in SV_Physics_Toss(). Entities are very often freed while thinking so this both prevents wasteful physics calculations and reduces the risk of writing data to a freed entity.

column13: Fix for some player sound bugs
column20:
This PR fixes some bugs with player sounds.

Player does pain sound in lava with godmode on

A small oversight by id. They check for the invul powerup but not the godmode flag. I just added the godmode flag check.

Player gib sound is rarely replaced by a footstep

This is a side-effect of change to sound priority ordering. Footstep events schedule the sound after the server frame has ends so it would override the gib sound. This was fixed by adding a check for player's health, and also by changing the channel the gib sound is played on (see later).

Player gib sound is played on the wrong channel

This is a bug in the original game and causes player death scream and gib sound to play over each other if the player is killed by a powerful shotgun blast or is gibbed very quickly after dying. It was playing on the CHAN_BODY channel but should have been CHAN_VOICE. This change is also consistent with monsters, which play their gibs on CHAN_VOICE.

Incorrect death sound plays some times

Another side-effect of the change to sound priority is that pain sound could override the death sound. This would happen if for example a shotgun blast first hurts the player and then kills him, all in a single server frame. Was easily fixed by adding a check for player health for the pain sound code.
I also prevented the death scream from overriding the gib sound which could happen after  I made both play on the same channel. Fixed by using the sounds variable to aggregate the sound effect, and then play it at the end of the server frame in P_DamageFeedback.
column21:
This PR fixes some bugs with player sounds.

Player does pain sound in lava with godmode on

A small oversight by id. They check for the invul powerup but not the godmode flag. I just added the godmode flag check.

Player gib sound is rarely replaced by a footstep

This is a side-effect of change to sound priority ordering. Footstep events schedule the sound after the server frame has ends so it would override the gib sound. This was fixed by adding a check for player's health, and also by changing the channel the gib sound is played on (see later).

Player gib sound is played on the wrong channel

This is a bug in the original game and causes player death scream and gib sound to play over each other if the player is killed by a powerful shotgun blast or is gibbed very quickly after dying. It was playing on the CHAN_BODY channel but should have been CHAN_VOICE. This change is also consistent with monsters, which play their gibs on CHAN_VOICE.

Incorrect death sound plays some times

Another side-effect of the change to sound priority is that pain sound could override the death sound. This would happen if for example a shotgun blast first hurts the player and then kills him, all in a single server frame. Was easily fixed by adding a check for player health for the pain sound code.
I also prevented the death scream from overriding the gib sound which could happen after  I made both play on the same channel. Fixed by using the sounds variable to aggregate the sound effect, and then play it at the end of the server frame in P_DamageFeedback.

It was playing on the CHAN_BODY channel but should have been CHAN_VOICE. This change is also consistent with monsters, which play their gibs on CHAN_VOICE.

Incorrect death sound plays some times

column13: cold attribute introduction proposal, applying for Sys_Error at first.
column21: I don't think these changes are worth the (potential) hassle. Quake II runs more than fast enough on all systems build in the last 15 years, the only exception might be cheap some ARM boards. And those are more GPU than CPU limited. Introducing compiler (family) specific attributes to the code might give some small speedups that no one really needs, at the cost of much worse portability to other compiler families like MSVC. And it diverges us even more from other source ports.

AFAIK timedemo 1 is only used for benchmarking, not for normal playing, so power consumption doesn't matter - or am I missing another usecase?
And you're only able to get 5000fps if you set vid_maxfps to 1000 - the default is 300, and it's totally reasonable to set it to an even lower value (for example if vsync causes trouble but you want to limit frames to save power and keep your system more quiet).

column21:
I have tailored it for openbenchmarking and have used +exec pts.cfg +set vid_fullscreen 0 +set r_retexturing 2 +set r_scale8bittextures 1 +set vid_maxfps 999 as common part of command line. ( https://openbenchmarking.org/innhold/b247efe97b6bf5340359e4aff1f34cf565aa1493 )
I was afraid that changes of limits of max_fps and minimal frame time would create some regressions.
Maybe best solution will be remove multiply to 5 and just make maxfps as 9999. @DanielGibson What do you think?

IIRC allowing maxfps > 1000 can fuck up things because then one frame can take < 1ms. But maybe that's only relevant for cl_async 0? Not sure.
However, frames <1ms only cause problems when actually playing, not when running demos.
So I'd argue that maxfps should remain as it is and there should be no restrictions at all with timedemo 1.

column21:
I'm not sure if I like it. Not from a code point of view. That looks more or less okay, I would just insist on undoing the change in frame.c. The timing is very fragile and the code is written verbose on purpose. The thing is that this change belongs in SDL rather than in the application. In the past, when we found problems with SDL, we discussed them with the upstream. Either through bug reports or through patches. This way everyone can benefit and we don't accumulate work arounds. If we have to include work arounds (for example the various bugs in SDL's windowing) we try to remove them at some point.
Let's hear what @DanielGibson has to say. The renderers are his field of expertise. My suggestion is to merge this as a temporary work around and to take the problem upstream.

column13: backends: Only enable ARM "RunFast" mode when targeting hardware FPU
column20:
Older ARM ABIs like Debian armel (ARMv5 EABI softfloat) don't use
or require a hardware FPU, so they can't execute the fmrx and fmxr
instructions. Only do this in hardfloat configurations that guarantee
VFP instructions are available.
The client might not be practically usable on ARM softfloat (although
nobody has reported that it isn't...) but the dedicated server is probably
fine, and ceasing to be able to build either would be a regression.
column21:

The client might not be practically usable on ARM softfloat (although
nobody has reported that it isn't...) but the dedicated server is probably
fine, and ceasing to be able to build either would be a regression.

column20:
Older ARM ABIs like Debian armel (ARMv5 EABI softfloat) don't use
or require a hardware FPU, so they can't execute the fmrx and fmxr
instructions. Only do this in hardfloat configurations that guarantee
VFP instructions are available.
The client might not be practically usable on ARM softfloat (although
nobody has reported that it isn't...) but the dedicated server is probably
fine, and ceasing to be able to build either would be a regression.
column21: Thank you!

column13: Fixed updated gunangles and gunoffset not always being sent to client
column20:
This (at least partially) addresses #735.
The problem is that client weaponframe is only updated if the gunframe changed, which does not happen during pauseframes which play randomly during the idle animations. gunangles and gunoffset are tied to PS_WEAPONFRAME, so if gunframe stays the same, gunangles and gunoffset updates are discarded, leading to the weapon bobbing stopping randomly and for random amounts of time.
This PR addresses the issue by sending PS_WEAPONFRAME segment if either the gunframe, gunangles or gunoffset changed, ensuring clients stay up to date on the weaponframe state.

column13: Fixed incorrect handling of - in late args and simplified code
column20: This PR addresses issue #757. It also greatly optimizes and shortens the code by skipping all the unnecessary string copying.
column21:
Yamagi and me discussed this a bit, and there's still this issue I mentioned in #757:

Are there legit usecases for - or at least + within an argv string? Like yquake2.exe +set game rogue+map whatever (without a space before +map that would turn rogue and +map into separate argvs)?

And while "legit" of course is always debatable, we fear that there's indeed .bat scripts from old mods and things like that which have a command without a space before the +.
While my example (+set game rogue+map whatever) would never have worked, because Cbuf_AddEarlyCommands() clears all argvs of +set and its arguments, +map whatever+set r_fullscreen 0 would have worked before but not with this change.
So while the way you're doing it now is better code (and definitely is what id should have done in the first place - after all they basically do the same in Cbuf_AddEarlyCommands()), probably it would be better to keep the code like it was before (i.e. do that concatenation of the argvs) and only add special handling to the "skip -" case that makes sure to ignore - if the previous character is not a space

column21:
A lot of really weird stuff is possible with this game's strings if you try hard enough. The question is what can be reasonably expected to happen in practice, and I'm not sure if I share your concerns. If you can find 2-3 concrete examples of this then I'll stand corrected, but from where I stand I see no incentive for people to think that not separating arguments would even work, let alone do it for any other reason than typo.
But it's up to you guys in the end. I do think id's code can be simplified still, doing just one string build instead of two. I'd be happy to take on the challenge and update this PR.

column13: Fixed incorrect handling of - in late args and simplified code
column20: This PR addresses issue #757. It also greatly optimizes and shortens the code by skipping all the unnecessary string copying.
column21:
My algorithm is pretty much completely unreworkable around having to build a string, so I just used your commit as a new base. I got rid of the build string and just called Cbuf_AddText directly for each scanned command. Not a big change or anything but then at least we get cleaner code, backwards compatibility and the bugfix all in one. Give this code a review and see if you can make it break (I couldn't).
And just to add to what I said above, you can't even chain early args together or it will break, so why someone would add a space between +set's but then decide to chain the late args (and that is without even knowing about early vs late args)... I don't even want to try to get into that frame of mind haha.

column13: Made the game able to handle entity overload better
column20:
This PR amortizes the issues reported in #759 by easing entity allocation policies.
These are the main points:

If no free entity is found according to the default policy, a second search is done, ignoring any freetime restrictions
New function G_SpawnOptional, instead of calling gi.error() it will return NULL, allowing the caller to react more gracefully
Made ThrowDebris, ThrowGib and AI tempgoals use G_SpawnOptional

column13: Fixed player_noise entity leak and improved stability surrounding player noises
column20:
This PR addresses issue #763 and also improves code stability.

Added a safety check to make sure the entity making the noise is actually a player
Made spawning of player_noise entities optional. If they fail to spawn, PlayerNoise() will not cause any sound event
Each time PlayerNoise() is called it will verify the mynoise variables of the player, and make an effort to repair them if needed
mynoise and mynoise2 can now be differentiated by spawnflags. self/weapon noises have none, while impact noises have spawnflag 1 set. This will help verification to re-link the noises correctly to the player in cases where impact noise appears first in the entity list. This is not crucial however, if the linking is incorrect it will correct itself quickly during gameplay and players are unlikely to notice any AI derps because of it.

column13: Re-enable thread-local stuff in stb_image, link winpthread statically
column20:
The real problem wasn't that thread-local variables are unsupported by
MinGW-w64, but that using them makes it link against libwinpthread-1.dll
Alternatively that lib can be linked statically, like we do now, at least
for the rendering backends that use stb_image.h/stb.c
For some reason it didn't work to add
-Wl,-Bstatic -lpthread -Wl,-Bdynamic in LDLIBS - it only worked without
the -Wl,-Bdynamic part, so it must be last on the linking commandline
(otherwise it'll try to link SDL2 statically as well).
refs #762

column21:
TBH no idea how much sense this makes, it's not like we're using threads, so stb_image doesn't really need thread-local variables anyway..
I mostly did this because I couldn't believe that mingw-w64 doesn't support thread-local variables - and as it turned out, it does, you only need libwinpthread for it.
