column21: Under Linux and likely all other platforms besides Windows this problem doesn't show up, because sdl2-config --libs adds -lpthread for the client and all renderer libs. Linking winpthreads under Windows would bring it onto par with the other platforms.  The question is, if linking winpthreads and spawning threads inside the renderer DLL can trigger some unwanted side effects. I don't think so, because Windows has this strange process model with very limited stacks anyways and the scary longjmp() is guaranteed to jump inside the main thread.
I'm not sure why git merged the player_noise entity leak commit along with my changes.
I've merged 0f80b29 by hand to avoid the garbage commits. Thank you for the contribution! :)

column13: Moved code hacks for waste3 to waste3.ent
column20:
This PR addresses #773 and removes the 2 waste3-related map hacks from the code as they are made redundant by the fixed ent file.
In addition to addressing those issues, the enr file also:

Fixed wrongly placed message for secret, the message is supposed to be in the target_secret entity but was in the trigger, causing a subtle sound glitch.
Fixed 2x monster_gunner with spawnflag 1024. The level designer most likely thought for a moment spawnflags were inclusive rather than exclusive, so viewed 1024 as hard-only rather than 768.
Added difficulty spawnflags to entities specific to monsters such as point_combat
Added not-deathmatch spawnflag (2048) to entities that are never used/accessible in DM
Start missing pumping sound effect for big pump mechanism in DM.

All changes are documented and trace-able by viewing the ent file with a text editor.

column21:
Just the high level stuff, I haven't looked into the code yet:

Do not add dependencies into the repository. Neither by importing the code, nor by submodules.
The build system must not download anything during build.
We don't want any editor or IDE specific stuff in the repo. A lesson we've learned a long time ago.
Contributed code (here miniz) must not be altered.

One big question remains: Why are all of these rather intruding changes in fragile and bug prone subsystems like the virtual filesystem are necessary? I understand that some users want better cmake support. But the ship for MSVC support has sailed years ago. We pondered a minimal invasive port for better integration into the MSVC debugger or WinDbg. Since then clang has added support for CodeView debug symbols and has become a first class citizen under Windows. When combined with the mingw libc it should be able compile the code with next to no changes.

column21:
I used to have a branch for MSVC support: https://github.com/DanielGibson/yquake2/tree/msvc
I updated it to current git master and fixed several issues (incl. alloca in loops): https://github.com/DanielGibson/yquake2/tree/MSVC-upd
Also fixed some general CMake issues there.
For external dependencies I checked out https://github.com/dhewm/dhewm3-libs/ and pointed CMake's YQUAKE2LIBS to the right directory, like -DYQUAKE2LIBS=c:/path/to/dhewm3-libs/i686-w64-mingw32

column13: Support building with Visual Studio (via CMake)
column20:
No idea if we want this, and I haven't tested it that much (but a bit at least), but it should generally be in an ok-ish shape now (no more alloca() in loops and such).
Also fixed some general issues in the CMakeLists.txt, like properly detecting the target CPU
Unfortunately, it currently requires VS2019 16.8 or newer; maybe this could be reduced to VS2015, if we can find a working alternative for _Alignas(TYPE) that doesn't require C11..
(#define YQ2_ALIGNAS_TYPE( TYPE )  __declspec(align(__alignof(TYPE))) looks like it should work, but doesn't, some compiler error about __builtin_alignof or sth like that)
UPDATE: Pushed a hack that should make it work with VS2015 and newer
Thanks to @bartekordek in #791 for inspiring me to dust up my old hacky msvc branch which this is based on :)

column21:
I'm not convinced if we / I really want this. These days Yamagi Quake II is (more or less) in maintenance mode. Nearly all features, which could by added, while staying compatible with Vanilla Quake II and not changing the gameplay, have been added. The feature requests, which are still open, are either some corner cases or rather trivial to implement. I've learned a lot from Yamagi Quake II, the project depicts my personal development from a university freshman to a IT professional. But life has moved on.  While we / I will continue to fix bugs, give user support and maybe implement some smaller new features, it's unlikely that Yamagi Quake II will ever see fast passed development or ground breaking new features again.
MSVC support by itself isn't a problem if done right. But, and that's a big but, it is another platform I / we need to support. It require test builds after code changes, there might be bug reports, etc. Exactly the points which prevented me from adding MSVC support even when I was spending whole weeksends hacking Yamagi Quake II. If it's just about debugger support, it might be better to look into refactoring the Makefile from hardcoded assumptions around mingw to something more generic which can use clang. clang can generate MSVC compatible debug symbols, I've used that for several other projects. When combined with the mingw libc it's just another gcc compatible platform without any maintenance overhead.

Unfortunately, it currently requires VS2019 16.8 or newer; maybe this could be reduced to VS2015, if we can find a working alternative for _Alignas(TYPE) that doesn't require C11..

column21:
MSVC support by itself isn't a problem if done right. But, and that's a big but, it is another platform I / we need to support. It require test builds after code changes

We already support kinda obscure platforms that we don't test ourselves, like Haiku or macOS.
As we're not planning to do major changes anymore, the risk of breaking a platform is relatively low, and if we do, the fix will (most probably) be small and easy as well.
So I think it's ok to not test all platforms regularly ourselves, and just fix things if/when someone reports it broken.
I'd also argue that most of the changes here are pretty harmless, the biggest/most invasive ones are:

All the changes to CMakeLists.txt - much of this isn't even MSVC-specific but works around a severe CMake bug (that they're considering expected behavior now)
The VLA stuff - yes, this is ugly, but most of it is in (parts of) GL1 code that we're unlikely to ever touch again

column13: Support building with Visual Studio (via CMake)
column20:
No idea if we want this, and I haven't tested it that much (but a bit at least), but it should generally be in an ok-ish shape now (no more alloca() in loops and such).
Also fixed some general issues in the CMakeLists.txt, like properly detecting the target CPU
Unfortunately, it currently requires VS2019 16.8 or newer; maybe this could be reduced to VS2015, if we can find a working alternative for _Alignas(TYPE) that doesn't require C11..
(#define YQ2_ALIGNAS_TYPE( TYPE )  __declspec(align(__alignof(TYPE))) looks like it should work, but doesn't, some compiler error about __builtin_alignof or sth like that)
UPDATE: Pushed a hack that should make it work with VS2015 and newer
Thanks to @bartekordek in #791 for inspiring me to dust up my old hacky msvc branch which this is based on :)
column21:
MSVC support by itself isn't a problem if done right. But, and that's a big but, it is another platform I / we need to support. It require test builds after code changes

We already support kinda obscure platforms that we don't test ourselves, like Haiku or macOS.

Good things with those, their specific code paths are minimal and well concealed, even a bizarre system (not saying it in condescending way but rather affectionate) like haiku which become more and more posix compliant as the releases occur. MSVC code path is a lot more invading ...

I'd also argue that most of the changes here are pretty harmless, the biggest/most invasive ones are:

All the changes to CMakeLists.txt - much of this isn't even MSVC-specific but works around a severe CMake bug (that they're considering expected behavior now)
The VLA stuff - yes, this is ugly, but most of it is in (parts of) GL1 code that we're unlikely to ever touch again


... and more bug prone. However, saying this I have nothing against MSVC support if everyone wants to go to that direction.

column13: Support building with Visual Studio (via CMake)
column20:
No idea if we want this, and I haven't tested it that much (but a bit at least), but it should generally be in an ok-ish shape now (no more alloca() in loops and such).
Also fixed some general issues in the CMakeLists.txt, like properly detecting the target CPU
Unfortunately, it currently requires VS2019 16.8 or newer; maybe this could be reduced to VS2015, if we can find a working alternative for _Alignas(TYPE) that doesn't require C11..
(#define YQ2_ALIGNAS_TYPE( TYPE )  __declspec(align(__alignof(TYPE))) looks like it should work, but doesn't, some compiler error about __builtin_alignof or sth like that)
UPDATE: Pushed a hack that should make it work with VS2015 and newer
Thanks to @bartekordek in #791 for inspiring me to dust up my old hacky msvc branch which this is based on :)
column21:
Good things with those, their specific code paths are minimal and well concealed, even a bizarre system (not saying it in condescending way but rather affectionate) like haiku which become more and more posix compliant as the releases occur.

Note I'm not dunking on Haiku here, I think it's great to support non-mainstream systems :-)
Just pointing out that we already have code that neither Yamagi nor me test (or even just build) ourselves.

... and more bug prone.

Sure, but again, it's not that much code using VLAs so it's manageable.
OTOH, supporting another compiler (that doesn't try to emulate GCC) makes the code a bit more portable overall, and MSVC's diagnostics actually help finding bugs, especially ones related to Win32 APIs, see those WCHAR changes.
And it opens the door to use debugging or profiling tools that are VS-centric when it makes sense, which can be a nice addition to the stuff we get from the gcc/clang/Linux world.
And of course supporting VS makes it more likely to get contributions from developers using Windows who are used to it.
Side-rant: I have no idea how people are productive with VS, I find using it for development (and not just compiling and a bit of debugging) painful because everything that has to do with code navigation like "find references" or especially "show call hierarchy" is ridiculously slow, but most developers who primarily use Windows, like most game developers, use it.. maybe it gets more usable with commercial plugins like resharper or visual assist or sth, I don't know. It is what it is 🤷‍♂️

column13: Support building with Visual Studio (via CMake)
column20:

Unfortunately, it currently requires VS2019 16.8 or newer; maybe this could be reduced to VS2015, if we can find a working alternative for _Alignas(TYPE) that doesn't require C11..

column21:
You know I've been using VS since the days of VC6 and the newer VS has come a long way.  It still has it's nitpicks.  The intellisense/find references/etc. would be nice if it could scan the project properly and the find references is kind of poor if it's a heavy C++ project with templates and overloads (lord have mercy if you're using it in a large .NET project).  However, I do think it's debugger is top notch.  GDB is usable, but makes things a lot harder than it needs to be.  There's front ends, but I've never been impressed with any of them.  It's trivial to readapt the try/catch exception handler code from R1Q2 to auto generate a dump that can be used to analyze crashed with VS.  I think that alone is a huge bonus.
Since your project is eligible for a free PVS Studio license you can integrate this easily in VS and then scan the project and you can simply double click go right to the offending line and fix it.
And yes, like you said, it may attract more Windows developers contributing.

column13: WIP: Add color light to soft render
column21:
BTW, I think the reason the original softrenderer was so bright (compared to the original GL renderer) is that apparently they used lightstyle_t::white for the light values, which is calculated as r+g+b - instead of (r+g+b)/3.0 as one might expect, which would return (roughly) the same brightness as the colored light.
(No idea if this is news for you, but I thought I'd mention it)

column13: Added cvar to define SDL gamepad's 'Back' button
column20:
This allows to redefine the button used as the "Esc key" in the SDL controller, by default the Back/Select/Minus (center left) button. Now it can be changed to the Start/Menu/Plus (center right) button, or even to the Guide/Home/PS button (middle of the gamepad, normally big). Requires a game restart to take effect.
Useful for people not happy with the current location of the button.

column13: Load gamecontrollerdb.txt for SDL2 joy mappings
column20:
This allows for the loading of gamecontrollerdb.txt, database of game controller mappings to be used with SDL2 controllers.
This is optional and its an alternative to the use of setting the SDL_GAMECONTROLLERCONFIG variable to use a gamepad.
It's practical for gamepads that change their GUID when used wired or bluetooth, e.g. Nintendo Switch Pro Controller on Linux.
The text file is usually obtained from https://github.com/gabomdq/SDL_GameControllerDB, and can be put in both the game or "config" directories.

column13: Full transition to SDL_GameController for gamepad usage
column20:
Currently, client/input/sdl.c handles input from buttons of gamepads/joysticks through SDL_Joystick, which depending on the OS and device may not be the best option. I.e. on MacOS High Sierra, DPad on the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is not recognized by SDL2 as a hat but as buttons, making it unsuitable to handle game menus (weird, because Cocoa detects it as a hat).
Using SDL_GameController increases compatibility of devices that can be used with YQ2, across any OS supported by SDL2.
"Unrecognized buttons" is no longer an issue since 2.0.14, which recognizes Xbox Elite paddles and other buttons on newer gamepads.
New features:

Named buttons, consistent across multiple gamepads.
Improved menu handling on controller: "A" to select, "B" to get back, "Y" to delete.
Separate menus to customize controller buttons, separated from the classic menu option (implements #802 ).
Hot swapping: disconnect/connect a controller with the game running with no other problem than a small delay.

column20:
packet framerate doesn't have to be lower than render framerate (unless render framerate is too high) => that 0.95 factor didn't really help
Improve the max framerate-handling with vsync, around vid_maxfps and the display refreshrate, especially considering the reported display refresh might be a bit too low
The packet framerate should be a fraction of the render framerate; and it should be between 45 and 90 to prevent movement glitches and such. Setting cl_maxfps to -1 now automatically chooses an appropriate packet framerate that meets those criteria.

If you want it extra smooth, make sure your render framerate is a multiple of 60Hz (by setting vid_maxfps accordingly, or use vsync with a 60Hz display)



Might fix (or at least improve) #819

column13: adding aimfix to double barrel shotgun
column20: adding aimfix to double barrel shotgun
column21:
I'm also the person who ported over aimfix from Berserker. I don't have access to a build system to check the application of aimfix to the shotgun, but a quick play does show the pellet spread is not centered so this could be welcome. Please note though that the fix isn't purely cosmetic, it actually properly centers the trajectory of projectiles as well.
Also as a passing comment, this is a pretty messy PR... Never do pull requests from your master branch, do a branch per change so the PR stays relevant. This PR can't be merged as is because all of your tinkering in master is now part of this PR.

column13: adding aimfix to double barrel shotgun
column20: adding aimfix to double barrel shotgun
column21:
If the aimfix for the shotgun is correct - I haven't checked - and calculates correct trajectories, we can merge it. That's what aimfix is for, fixing the slightly broken trajectory calculation for users who them correct.
The customization stuff isn't really in scope for YQ2. While we have added features in the past, we stick to feature that enhance the 'out of box experience'. Widescreen support, HTTP download, the teleport command for debugging, fixed bullet trajectories... We avoided "unnecessary" features and, at least when possible, everything which changes the game <-> server <-> client interactions. So this would be better done in a mod.

column21:
i prepared the pull request from a branch of my fork, only the code used for aimfix double barrel shotgun is used.
i noticed that the double barrel shotgun did not have aim fix, when i changed its variables to reduce horizontal spread...
suddenly it was much more noticeable that all bullets hit on the bottom right side of the aiming cross.
i picked the same code used to fix the aim of the shotgun, and i copied in the necessary spot to achieve the correction effect. and it worked.
with the default spread of the double barrel shotgun the not fixed bullets appear to hit 95% below the cross and 25% on its left side while 75% on the right side.

column20:
When a key/button name is too long, and its bound to an inventory element, its display in the inventory screen misaligns the item it is bound to, even pushing it out of the inventory frame.

This single-line fix limits its display to the maximum of 6 characters the inventory screen allows.

Cannot see what controller stick the quad damage is bound to. Maybe the key number to string bindings should have long and short abbreviated names? Or scrolling text?

True, but both of those solutions require much bigger, more intrusive work. What I'm proposing here is much simpler, clear to understand and guaranteed to not produce any further errors. This is, at worst, a "good enough" patch until either of what you mention gets implemented.
Also, for now, a truly interested player can check out the new gamepad buttons' menus to see what it is bound to quad damage.

There was similar issue recently involving the "help computer" and the "nightmare" difficulty setting being displayed through it.

In that one, no solution left everyone happy either. The problems of targeting 320x240 resolution :)

column13: Check >= maxsize in Info_SetValueForKey().  Found by ASAN.
column20:
This might be rare, but I found in Daikatana (which uses the same exact code here) that ASAN triggered a warning from the *s = 0; at the end of Info_SetValueForKey().  This can happen if you have a lot of SERVERINFO (especially custom ones like 'admin', 'email', and 'website') flagged CVARs and someone does a /serverinfo packet.  In Daikatana, it was more prevalent use of UB since the same command was sent every time a map transition happened on a public server to send the serverinfo stats to the gamespy master server.
This bug exists in R1Q2 and all varieties of Info_SetValueForKey() out there that I am aware of.  So the mods would need this fix as well.
